Title: Christopher Effgen - Comments
Comment: Christopher Effgen 6921 Weimer Anchorage, AK 99502 907-248-8363 Department of Transportation, Documentary Services Division, Attention: Docket Section, Room PL401, Docket Number: OST-1996-1437, SVC-124, Washington, DC 20590 RIN 2105-AD23. NOTICE: This is a comment and objection to proposed rules and is required to be considered and determined pursuant to the procedures applicable to the adoption of Federal Regulations. February 14, 2003 Re: Proposal to Implement a System of Records Under the Privacy Act of 1974, i.e., to modify the privacy act so as to enable background checks on United States citizens under circumstances where background checks were not previous authorized. 68 Federal Register No 10, pp 2101-2103 Dear Office of Secretary, The following constitute my objections to the System of Records Under the Privacy Act of 1974 that DOT intends to implement as published in 68 Federal Register No 10, pp 2101-2103. Kindly consider my objections, withdraw the proposed rule, or modify the rule in accordance with the objections. I also request that you place these objections in the public record and that you respond to me directly and publicly with regard to my objections. Very truly yours, Christopher Effgen 1. Title: Electronic Frontier Foundation

Title: Travis Coppock
Comment:
Dear Sir,

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. I feel this will be an invasion of privacy and civil liberties, and respectfully urge the rule to be withdrawn.

Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Scott S. Aldinger
Comment:
Dear Director, 
 
 I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.


The proposal uses open-ended terms like "associated information" and "proprietary information," which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the "safeguards" described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale -- making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.
 
 


The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties. For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.


Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.


Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 
 
 For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 
 
 Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 
 
 Sincerely,

Scott Aldinger
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: David Watson
Comment: I am writing to request that DOT withdraw this proposal.  In addition the issues of privacy, which I believe are extremely important, I am conserned that the said proposal will 1) be used in unintended (and inevitably hurtful ways (e.g. imagine someone who is falsely accused of being a terrorist - and don't forget that the potiential will always exist for misuse once any such database is created), 2) provide a false sense of security (like, e.g., confiscating finger nail clippers - the real problem is people, not the systems ability to control/track people).  Rather than fear and reactionary policies we need to examine the _real_ problems here.  Those problems aren't that we can't monitor, track and control movement.  The real problems are much deeper.  Please reconsider.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Arielle D. Patrice
Comment:
Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.  Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act’s protections.  By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties – without increasing security or making the public safer.  

The proposal uses open-ended terms like “associated information” and “proprietary information,” which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the “safeguards” described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale – making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.

The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties.  For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.  

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Arielle Patrice

Title: Scott Hall

Title: Frank J. Tobin
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.  The Categories of Records in the System contains extremely open-ended terms such as "proprietary data", "associated data", and "public source information".  Such terms do not place practical limits on what data is gathered.

Furthermore, the retention time of information on "individuals who are deemed to pose a possible risk to transportation security" of 50 years is astronomical and without qualification.

Given the immense public outcry over the proposed Total Information Awareness Program, this similarly-minded proposal needs more public attention and scrutiny, and more concrete language describing what privacy and civil rights of Americans are being chipped away at.

I ask that the proposal be withdrawn, re-considered, and re-presented with much more public awareness.

Title: Dave Owen
Comment:
It has taken me more than three years to correct a $20 error made by a public utility company that ended up on my credit report as charged-off debit. In that time, I spend tens of hours on the phone attempting to determine the purpose of the $20 charge, and made tens of attempts to pay it (just to get rid of it), but the utility in question refused to acknowledge the debt owed...even as they continued to negatively update my credit report every few months.

Even now, though I have been assured that it is taken care of (after officially challenging it with the credit companies and having them once again affirm it, I used this to get the utility to accept the $20), it continues to impact my life negatively. I cannot qualify for top-tier auto loans, my first mortgage was thrown into jeopardy at the last minute, and the sheer volume of stress has been at times overwhelming.

Please consider that this occurred because of a single error on a public utility's part, and I have only been able to (supposedly) correct it by (a) having access to the information in my file, (b) paying $20 that I didn't really owe, and (c) having laws that allowed me to contest the incorrect data and demand contact information for the person who claimed it was correct.

With this action, you will be creating a database that contains information about me that could have an equally (if not moreso) negative impact on my life. An erroneous piece of information accidentally placed on my file could (at the very least) prevent me from flying and expose me to prejudice from flight and security personnel, and (theoretically) expose me to surveillance, detainment or arrest. Unlike my credit report situation, I will have no recourse to (a) have access to the information in my file, (b) take steps to correct that data, or (c) have the right to contest the incorrect data and demand to know who placed it there.

I sincerely hope you will reconsider this ill-conceived plan, or at least make it possible to access your own record, contest incorrect information and file a comment if the information cannot be corrected, as we are allowed to do with credit reports. This will not solve the problem, but will at least allow individuals some power without diluting the stated purpose of this measure.

Additionally, please consider limiting either the type of information stored or the individuals who have access to it. Again, as with the credit report, information of this nature in the wrong hands will make identity theft and other crimes easy for those with access...and the more people with access, the more likely they are to believe that they'd get away with such activity.


A single credit report error has had a significant negative effect on my life; at least I could review the data and take steps to correct it. Your proposal has the potential to cause equal or greater harm, yet has no provision for oversight or correction of incorrect data. This is an extremely bad thing, and I hope you will reconsider.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Andy Dooley
Comment:
According to the Jan. 15 Federal Register, the Department of Transportation seeks to create a massive database which is exempt from the provisions of the Privacy Act of 1974.

This system, which would store information on every air traveler, is ill-defined.  The definitions of the information to be collected are broad enough to allow almost any personal data to be tracked.  Operating such a system without the protections of the Privacy Act removes all public oversight.  The public has no way of knowing what data is collected by them or verifying its accuracy.

It is doubtful whether such a system would improve public safety.  This system, as proposed, will contain information on a vast number of innocent travelers.  It is unclear whether such a vast collection could be promptly and effectively searched to find criminal activity.  No matter what search criteria are used, the chance for false positives is high.

It is also doubtful whether the Department of Transportation can secure such a database.  The potential of abuse is obvious, should such a database be compromised.  Depending on the data collected--which, again, could include almost anything--any compromise of this database could release financial information, credit card numbers, travel itineraries and destinations and confidential details from law enforcement investigations.  Nothing in this proposal indicates that adequate safeguards will be in place for this data.  The potential for compromise of such a database is quite real, as evidenced by the recent problems with Tricare.

When I look over this proposal, I see an ill-conceived system which would introduce several new privacy risks for the American air traveler.  I see the increased expense of a vast program to collect, store and secure data.  I see a process attempting to hide from public scrutiny and from the protections afforded us under the 1974 Privacy Act.

I do not see any tangible benefits, and I do not see anything that would outweigh the above concerns.


This system presents grave privacy risks and unnecessary added expense.  It does not present any obvious benefit.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Ronald D. Morley
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to the proposal to build a database of information concerning air travelers.  This information will supposedly be used to help protect the U.S. against terrorist activity.  However, it seems to me that this proposal would do little to increase our safety, but would result in a significant reduction in the civil liberties of American citizens.  It is during times such as this, when it is so tempting to institute efforts to increase the safety of Americans that we need to be careful that those efforts do not impinge on the very civil liberties that have made our country a beacon of hope to millions around the world.

As I understand the proposed action a database of information regarding the travel habits of everyday Americans would be gathered and held in secrecy.  Individuals would have no right to examine the information gathered about them.  Without such access persons would be unable to correct any misinformation in their file.  Furthermore, such a system, by targeting anyone who travels by air effectively treats all persons as potential criminals and allows dossiers to be assembled about them without their being convicted - or even suspected of - any particular crime.  Such surveillance activities are reminiscent of those undertaken by such notorious organs of state repression as the former Soviet KGB and the Nazi Gestapo.  Such screening and surveillance activities are a direct assault upon the freedoms that Americans have traditionally and by law enjoyed.  I urge you to reject this proposal as the ineffective crime fighting tool that it would be.  No such system deserves a place in American society and its adoption would mark yet another step along the path of increasing the police powers of the state.

Thank you for your consideration,
Ronald D. Morley

Title: Duane L. Gustavus
Comment: I wish to go on record as opposing the DoT's attempt to evade full disclosure of information gleaned on airline passengers.  Exempting such data collection from the provisions of The Privacy Act of 1974 is clearly a mockery of the intent of the act.  The historic abuses of such invasions of privacy are legion, and the very least compensation for your stalking me should be access to the data you store about me.

Title: Johnny Davis, Jr.
Comment:
Dear Director,

I am writing to express my oppositon to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) evisecerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties without increasing security or making the public safer.

The proposal uses open-ended terms like "associated information" and propietary information," which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the "safeguards" described in this proposal are woefully insufficient, this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people looks small by contrast.

The routine uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties. For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information(including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information)could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel. Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate.

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn.

Thank you for your time and the opportunityto voice my concerns.

Sincerely,
          Johnny Davis Jr.

Title: TTD Software
Comment:
I just wanted to say that this is perhaps one of the most offensive ideas I have seen come out of the DOT.  Frankly, it's an invasion of privacy, and the fact that an exemption from the privacy act is sought is proof of that.
Whether or not 200,000 negative comments come in, like happened for the FDIC's "Know your Customer" proposal, this is a terrible idea with a great potential for abuse.

The ONLY reason I can imagine that this is even being proposed is that somebody wants to know more about travel for the purpose of tracking potential terrorists; however! You've already got such a system in place.

So, yeah, this is worthless, ditch it.  It's a threat to everyone.


I just wanted to say that this is perhaps one of the most offensive ideas I have seen come out of the DOT.  It's a violation of privacy, and there's a reason we have that Privacy Act that this new policy will be exempt from.

So, yeah, this proposal is very bad, ditch it.  It's a threat to everyone.

Title: Seth L. Buckley
Comment:
February 21, 2003

Documentary Services Division
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-101
Docket No. OST-1996-1437
Department of Transportation, SVC-124
Washington, DC 20590

Dear Director,

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.  Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act’s protections.  By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties – without increasing security or making the public safer.

The proposal uses open-ended terms like “associated information” and “proprietary information,” which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the “safeguards” described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale – making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.

The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties.  For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate.

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn.

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns.

Sincerely,

Seth Buckley
5226 Little Sandy Drive
Raleigh, NC  27616

Title: Thomas C. Caloz
Comment:
Dear Director, 

Privacy Act of 1974, as currently written, is a bad idea.
The Department of Transportation's proposed exemptions makes the title into a parody of itself.
The proposal uses open-ended terms like "associated information" and "proprietary information," which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the "safeguards" described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale --  the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people is an example of the danger.

There is no method outlined to verify or challenge any data. Normal screwups and malicious actors would generate Kafka-esque torment for many innocent people. Secret snitches and untracable informants were a bad aspect of the old Soviet Union. They do not belong in our Country.
Abuses and thefts of databases are a daily headline in the newspapers. Setting up a database that is designed with no corrective procedure, with no accountability and no limits on intrusiveness is repugnant to common sense.
It will do less than nothing to help security. It would bleed money away from any other security efforts, and it would waste security personnel's time in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.
For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Tom Caloz



Privacy Act of 1974, as currently written, is a bad idea.

the proposed rule should be withdrawn

Title: Bruce Stephenson
Comment: The Dept. of Transportation's proposed "system of records" is poorly thought out. Rather than justifying the need to collect the huge amount of information on citizens that they want, they simply request exemption from the Privacy Act. American citizens expect better from their government. It is fundamental to our constitution that we are not required to trust our government--that's why the system of checks and balances is there. Hurried attempts to deal with the present situation must be done within the law--in this case the Privacy Act.

Title: Scott R. Looney
Comment:
Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-101 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.

The proposal uses open-ended terms like "associated information" and "proprietary information," which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the "safeguards" described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale -- making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.

The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties. For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

Also, the inability of individuals who would appear on this list to verify or correct their personal information in this database is a serious drawback, and more resembles the actions of a police state intent on monitoring its citizenry than a democracy.  We should not trade our freedoms and our right to privacy for a dubiously devised solution without far-ranging and serious study as to its limitations.

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time,

Sincerely,

Scott R. Looney

Title: Matthew C. Davis
Comment:
I oppose the DOT's proposed establishment of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.

A system such as the one vaguely described is an anathema to a free society.  This appears to me to be an open-ended system without limitations on the types of information to be tracked and stored.

I'm quite weary of being singled out for "comprehensive" security searches every time I fly.  Especially when I consider that they do absolutely nothing to increase security.


Furthermore, use of the system amounts to a government permit to travel via air... reminiscent of the former UUSR's restraints on its citizens' free movement.

For these and several other reasons, this proposal should be withdrawn.

Thank you for the opportunity to air my concerns to you.

For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.
Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.  
Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 
For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,
Bradley R. Bowman

Title: Usman Chaudhary
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am writing to express my opposition to the establishment of an "Aviation Security Screening Records" database, and I request that the DOT immediately withdraw the proposal.  To create a database of the scale proposed by the DOT would undoubtedly lead to massive privacy violations and identity theft, as well as abuse of information by federal employees.  Additionally, the existing computer-assisted passenger pre-screening system (CAPPS) already in use by airlines makes this system redundant.  Taxpayer dollars should be used to improve CAPPS and enforce its use among airlines.


I oppose the proposal - I request its WITHDRAWAL - it will lead to privacy violations and identity theft - CAPPS is sufficent

Title: Robert D. Plankers
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.

The proposal uses open-ended terms like "associated information" and "proprietary information," which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the "safeguards" described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale -- making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.



The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties. For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Shamim Mohamed, Phd
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of
Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under
the Privacy Act of 1974.

1. The proposed system is overbroad. The stated purpose is to
improve aviation security; however the "Routine Uses" of the
information are much broader. The proposal uses open-ended terms
like "associated information" and "proprietary information,"
which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records
being tracked.

2. The safeguards proposed by the system are far too weak
considering the broad scope of the information to be saved. This
will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale --
making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive
personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only"
500,000 military people look small by contrast.

3. The subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of
this information (including public source information,
proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result
in law-abiding people being denied the right to
travel. Furthermore, the proposed rule offers individuals
inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any
type of infringement of their rights. There is no way for
incorrect information to be corrected by an individual.

4. An individual may only see information provided by the
individual.  Furthermore, since an individual must identify the
system from which the individual is seeking records, and include
a general description of the records sought, it is likely that
large parts of it will not be available. There is no way for an
individual to examine any records collected by governmental
agencies or corporations.

5. Implementation of this rule would probably make us more
vulnerable since it would mire security personnel in pointlessly
scrutinizing the large volumes of data collected on innocent
travelers.

6. At a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total
Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by
Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection,
storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about
virtually every US citizen, permanent resident, and visitor,
should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate.

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn.

Shamim Mohamed, Ph.D.
3035 Castro St.
San Francisco CA 94131



I oppose the proposed action strongly. The proposed system is overbroad both in the information to be collected and its intended uses. The safeguards proposed are too weak. It offers no way for incorrect information to be corrected by an individual. An individual may only see information provided by the individual -- not any information collected by the government or corporations. It will also swamp security personnel in vast volumes of data. Information collection of this scale on U.S. Citizens should be subjected to much greater Congressional and public scrutiny.

Title: Robert X. Cadena
Comment:
Feb. 18, 2003 

Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-101 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.  

I am only too familiar with incorrect information being associated with my record by a government agency.  For the past year and a half the California DMV has associated my record with an incorrect texas driving record indicating that the owner of this record had several infractions and accidents.  My personal record is clean but after my insurance company reviewed the incorrect driving record my rate went up more than 1000 dollars extra a month.  Moreover, my record became associate with an AKA which  I had never admited and for which my name has no relation at all.  I had to coordinate with the DMV in Texas and California and handle the problems with my insurance agency.  Thankfully a year and a half after the existence of this incorrect record came to my attention the matter was resolved and I now enjoy a spotless driving record.  This is nothing compared to the types of errors that may occur in a system such as that proposed.

Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Acts protections.  By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties  without increasing security or making the public safer.  

The proposal uses open-ended terms like associated information and proprietary information, which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the safeguards described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale  making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.

The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties.  For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.  

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Robert Cadena

Title: Sumana S. Harihareswara
Comment: This proposal (the system of records) is simply a bad idea.  Passengers need the ability to view and correct information about them, in accordance with standard practice and with the Privacy Act of 1974!  How am I to tell a fallible system that it has made a mistake before terrible abuses of power or other tragedies occur?  This system will not make us any safer and will erode civil liberties even further, not to mention making identity theft even easier.  We need more public discussion and consideration to really know what will make us safer, so I request that you withdraw the proposed rule.  Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Graham Freeman
Comment:
I have been denied credit due to erroneous information in my credit report, and offered credit at unattractive terms due to the same situation.  Several among my friends and family members have been victims of identity theft due to lax security on the part of several of their creditors & vendors.  As a result, I do not trust external parties (including airline companies, government agencies, etc.) to properly safeguard my confidential information.  They simply do not have my best interests at heart.

If parties without my best interests at heart are going to be privy to my confidential information, then at the very least I should be afforded the opportunity to easily review and correct said information without paying any fees or going through undue beuraucratic hassle.  

Otherwise, I simply won't participate in activities in which I'm required to disclose my confidential information.  Alternatively, if I am forced to participate and I am not confident that all parties involved will properly safeguard my information, I will provide false information as a form of civil disobedience.

I am far from alone in my viewpoint.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Andrew H.
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.

This proposal inpinges harshly upon my civil liberties, especially as I am unable to correct information gathered, or opt-out of the system. 

If this system is adopted I will likely abandon airlines as a means of transportation, at least domestically, simply to avoid this incursion into my private affairs.

For these reasons, simple though they may be, but true, I hope that the proposed rule be withdrawn

Thank you,
Andrew

Comment:
The Department has not satisfied the statutory notice and

comment requirements; the proposals exceed the Department's

statutory authority; the Department has failed to consider

factors required by statute to be considered; the Department

has failed to conduct the required analysis of regulatory

impacts; and the proposed system of records and its uses

would be unconstitutional.



[See attached PDF file of comemnts for complete abstract,

whihc produced an error in the DMS Web upload system.]
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Raj Seshadri
Comment:
Dear Director,

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.

The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties. For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

For these reasons alone, the proposed rule should be withdrawn.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Thomas K. Spindler
Comment:
Feb. 18, 2003
 
Documentary Services Division
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-101
Docket No. OST-1996-1437
Department of Transportation, SVC-124
Washington, DC 20590
 
Sir -
 
I must strenuously object to the DoT's proposed 'system of record under
the Privacy Act of 1974', Aviation Security Screening Records. Adopting
such a far-reaching system with so little in the way of safeguard for
privacy or other civil liberties seems like it's ripe for abuse - whether
internally by the government, or externally by some malicious outsider.
 
In addition, the existence of such a system would call for increased
workload of airport security personnel, an already overworked and
understaffed group.
 
Finally, it troubles me that such a comprehensive system would be 
adopted without public input; these sorts of privacy concerns are
becoming increasingly important to the citizenry at large, and
should be subjected to intense scrutiny.
 
With these concerns, the proposed rule should be withdrawn.
 
Yours,
Tom Spindler
150 S Pastoria 
Sunnyvale CA 94086

Title: Michael R. Harmon
Comment:
Feb. 18, 2003 

Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-101 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974. Exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.

The proposal uses open-ended terms like "associated information" and "proprietary information," which essentially place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. Given the volume of personal information being stored, the "safeguards" described in this proposal are woefully insufficient; this will inevitably lead to privacy violations on a massive scale -- making the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.



The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties. For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  Compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

Rather than improving security, implementation of this rule would probably make us more vulnerable by miring security personnel in pointlessly scrutinizing innocent travelers.

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,
Michael R. Harmon

Title: Dan Foreman
Comment:
22.Feb.2003 

Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-101 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 


I wish to express my strong opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed adoption of a system of records under the Privacy Act of 1974.  

I believe that exempting such an extremely broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act (as proposed) completely guts the protections the of the Privacy Act.  

By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties. Worse, it would do so without increasing security or making the public safer.  

The proposals use of open-ended terms (e.g., associated information and proprietary information") place no limits on the Category of Records being tracked. 

Given both the breadth and the volume of personal information being stored, the safeguards described in this proposal are completely and woefully insufficient. It is virtually certain that this proposal will lead to privacy violations on a massive scale. 

For example, this would make the recent theft of medical data and other sensitive personal information held by TriWest Corporation of "only" 500,000 military people look small by contrast.

The Routine Uses described for this information will needlessly harm civil liberties.  For example, the subjectivity and inaccuracy of many of the sources of this information (including public source information, proprietary data, and law enforcement information) could result in law-abiding people being denied the right to travel.  

Further compounding the problem is that the proposed rule offers individuals completely inadequate Record Access Procedures, and no recourse for any type of infringement of their rights.

This rule would not improve security. Rather, it would probably make us more vulnerable by causing security personnel to pointlessly scrutinize and victimize totally innocent travelers.  

At a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, absolutely MUST be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 


Dan Foreman

Title: Rose Barnstable
Comment: The continual invasion of our civil liberties must stop.  Attempting to solve the problems that caused 9/11 by collecting, storing, and using personal information about US citizens and non-US citizens living in and/or visitng this country is tantamount to creating a police state.  The safeguards put in place in almost all cases are useless; I know, I spent 35 years in the computer business.  The proposed rule should be withdrawn..  and it should make the front page of all newspapers and prime time news to let the American public know what is once again trying to be done to us behind our backs by an administration bent on rescinding many of our most basic and cherished rights.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: EPIC
Comment: The TSA has failed to provide sufficient information for the public to contribute meaningfully to this rule-making procedure.  The TSA proposes  to collect passenger manifest information on all airline travelers and store it in a large centralized database.  The TSA proposes to maintain information on certain individuals deemed a security risk for fifty years.  This proposal does not comport with Privacy Act values, or with Constitutional values of freedom of association and freedom to travel.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: The Center for Democracy and Technology
Comment:
The Center for Democracy and Technology (CDT) comments on the 

Transportation Security Administration's Privacy Act Notice regarding 

the Aviation Security Screening Records system.  CDT expresses 

concerns about the privacy implications of the new data collection 

and analysis authority that TSA seek to implement, and urges TSA to 

adopt privacy guidelines.

Title: Brian Clark
Comment:
Today I heard of the CAPS II program, and that the deadline for comment is
today.  Unfortunately, I can not find any information on it.  The only
information I have so far is hearsay, but what I've heard sound very
irresponsible, if it is in fact true.

I have no objection to computer-assisted pre-screening to determine if
someone should get a higher level of screening at the airport.  However,
what I've heard is that this database will be open to anyone, including
the news media.  There is (or at least should be) a fairly obvious line
drawn between the agencies working for my security and the agencies trying
to gain my information in order to sell it to marketing firms and god
knows who else.

The information gathered and contained in this database should be
absolutely confidential, available only to those people who are working to
improve security, and the person who is the subject of the data collection.  Perhaps this is already the plan, but that is not what I have heard.

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,
Brian Clark


The CAPS II program information on passengers should be available ONLY to security personnel and the individual about whom the data has been gathered.  This is to protect the privacy of the individual passengers.

Title: Jennifer Smith
Comment:
America is a nation of travellers.  Its industry depends on the business trip and its sanity depends on the vacation.  The "Notice of Proposed Rulemaking - Privacy Act; Maintenance of and Access to Records Pertaining to Individuals; Amendment (9C-1)" will prevent individuals from verifying that the records that TSA maintains on them are correct.  
All agencies collect data, and all make mistakes.  Preventing individuals from examining their records prevents them from correcting them.  Some extremely embarassing mistakes may and will happen to innocent travelers (in the same sense that #### happens).  This proposed amendment will do nothing to deter or detect the actual terrorist, who is much more fastidious with his paper trail than the average Joe or Jane.  Please do not make this law.  


Please read this.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Geri Silveira
Comment:
Did you read George Orwell's "1984?"  Well, this frightening story of government intrusion into private lives is here today--only 19 years late.  The CAPPS II program, and other government surveillance programs of  individual Americans, are an egregious afront to the very basis of our liberties.  Stop these programs immediately.  Find another way to combat terrorism, or you risk becoming the very tyrants you are trying to eliminate.

Title: Mel Mann

Documentary Services Division

Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the
information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  The proposal to exempt such a potentially broad
and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive
amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties  without
increasing security or making the public safer.

By exempting all risk assessment reports and the information contained in those reports, this third notice suffers from the same
defects as the previous two notices published in the Federal Register.  Exempting risk assessment reports and the information
that populates them would remove accountability to the individual.  Individuals would not be allowed to access the information
contained about them, nor would they be notified if files were being kept on them or her. This is very serious in light of the fact
that investigatory material could be included in these reports  without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the
information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 

Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the
exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals  the very thing
the Privacy Act was passed to prevent. 

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy
scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information
about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Mel Mann

Title: Name Unknown
Comment:
Would it have caught Timothy Mcveigh? No

A Lay Explanation of the MIT Research Paper "Carnival Booth: An Algorithm for Defeating the Computer-Assisted Passenger Screening System"

By Russell L. Brand

Imagine a world where you knew who all the terrorists were in advance. It is a much simpler world than the one we have. There would be no waiting in airport security lines.

While we don't have that, some people think we are in a world where we know who the terrorists ARE NOT. And in that world, we can avoid searching the people we know are safe and devote all (or most of) our effort just to the people were aren't sure of. It sounds good. Some of us avoid being hassled and the system moves faster for everyone.

BUT ...

What if we are occasionally wrong? Just a few of these SEEMINGLY SAFE people are really terrorists. They'd slip by with us good upstanding citizens.

And what if the terrorist organizations sent all their folks on a few test trips? After a few trips, they would know which ones got searched each time and which ones never got searched. Then they would use the ones that had never gotten searched on their mission, knowing that these SEEMINGLY SAFE people (who were really terrorists) could more easily get onto the planes.

Unfortunately, the efforts to target our searching attention, rather than better protecting us and more efficiently using our resources, instead telegraphs what we know and allows the bad guys to have a better chance of out maneuvering us.

While the intuition of this is easy to understand, it took a team of leading mathematicians at MIT to prove that it is true and to show that their are no simple fixes to the targeted approach. And the implications of their findings cannot be ignored.

It is critically important to not let a terrorist know whether or not he is a suspect until the moment we capture him. And unfortunately, that means long lines for us all.

Title: William Daul
Comment:
There was a time when the government looked out for our rights instead of taking them away as you do now.  If the old time communists could look at this country now they would be so jealous...we have all the means to keep track of all of us.  There are no rights to privacy and your CAPPS-II is another major step down the road to complete dictatorship...with an illusion that elections actually mean anything.

You are doing the wrong thing at implementing this act.  Why does everyone have to suffer because of a few?  Your children will never know what freedom was.  Is that what you want.  They will be followed through life by governments and business.  If the airlines implement CAPPS-II I will avoid flying as much as possible and hope that all the airlines end up like PanAm or other memories.  

You are contributing to the downfall of this country that could once again be a place to be proud of.  A police state isn't what I was born into, but it is becoming a reality.  God help us, because I don't think you or the current administration are capable of seeing what you are doing.

Thanks for taking the time to read these comments...please CONSIDER not implementing this complete invasion of privacy!

--bill daul

Title: Gregory S. Lauer
Comment:
Dear Director,

As someone who has been subject to credit fraud and identity theft, I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  I would not be allowed to access the information contained about me to rectify any errors contained in them - a process that I have needed to use to clean up the mess caused by credit card fraud and identity theft. Please withdraw the proposed rule until these concerns can be addressed.

Sincerely,

Gregory Lauer
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: John H. Hilditch
Comment: The far reaching, Orwellian implications of such an intrusive piece of legislation are completely unacceptable in any form.  I do not believe that a case has been made that proves this proposed legislation will enhance or ensure the safety of US citizens sufficiently to offset its incremental attack on our remaining (yet rapidly diminishing) remnants of privacy. Those who would do us harm will find other ways to format their evil, while the far reaching implications of this legislation will place our citizenry more under a microscope than we currently are.  Inevitably, this information is bound to find its way, in some form, to other, non-governmental organizations. Such an inevitability will affect our credit ratings, insurance purchases, health care and other, unforeseen elements in the fabric of our lives.  It is poorly contrived, knee-jerk, reactive legislation that should be dismissed as a bad idea, possibly based upon good intentions, but suspect nonetheless.  I urge you to not pass this legislation in any form.  Sincerely, John Hilditch.

Title: Richard Blackburn
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the
information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  Surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, and a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should not be allowed without very clear need and national discussion.  In the arena of airline travel it will not provide increased security, and it will undermine our Constitutional protections of privacy.  Ultimately, it will destroy our trust in the Federal Government.  Pragmatically, a rule like this will destroy our already weak airline industry as many people will forgo air travel, before giving up their cherished privacy.

Title: Thomas R. Work
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Thomas J. Hillgardner
Comment: The Framers of the U.S. Constitution would not approve of any system that permits the government to collect information on every citizens¿ movements, or demand that they provide personally identifying information merely for moving about the country. Nor does the new climate of terrorism since 9/11 justify the regulations.  The reinforcement of cockpit doors and the adoption of new cockpit security protocols is all that was needed to prevent the seizure of commercial airliners by terrorists for use as guided missiles.  Securing the passengers is already accomplished by metal detectors and x-rays which are anonymous searches and do not permit government to collect the personally identifying information that is called for by these regulations.  If government has done its job by sufficiently insuring that commercial airliners have reinforced cockpit doors and where it is conducting metal detection and x-ray examination of passengers to insure that they are not armed, the proposed regulations will not add any appreciable quantity of security while constituting an enormous invasion of personal privacy on the millions of air travellers who are committing no crime whatsoever.  Many of the new provisions wherein government has asked individuals to give up personal privacy and certain personal liberties for the sake of ¿security¿ are unneccesary and are going down the wrong path to find security.  If the government wants to provide more security for its citizens,it should reconsider some of its foreign policy objectives that motivate people to fly planes into buildings.  And not because people fly planes into buildings, but because it is the right thing to do.

This is very serious in light of the fact that investigatory material could be included in these reports  without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 

Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals  the very thing the Privacy Act was passed to prevent. 

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Nicholas F. McPhee
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the DoT's proposed modifications to the Privacy Act of 1974.  There are enormous possibilities of abuse in the proposed system, putting the privacy and civil liberaties of all air travellers at very real risk.

In a democracy there needs to be wide public debate on issues of this sort (which there hasn't been on this issue), and citizens must have the freedom to review government records so that these can be challenged when appropriate.

For these reasons I urge you to withdraw this proposal and explore other, less damaging mechanisms to address the issues at hand.  

Crucial in this is a clear identification of what problems we're trying to solve, and a plan that is clearly focussed on solving those specific problems in a manner that is both effective and in keeping with the civil liberties that crucial to our concept of America as a democracy.

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Dr. Nicholas Freitag McPhee


I urge you to withdraw this proposal and explore other, less damaging mechanisms to address the issues at hand.

Title: Denis Hughes
Comment:
I totally object to implementation of CAPPS II as an unwarranted and useless invasion of privacy.  The data you intend to collect has no logical bearing on terrorist tendencies.  Further, there is no way of guaranteeing the security of the data.

This program will not only inconvenience and embarrass honest citizens for erroneous data, but it will do nothing to deter real terrorists as they will be able to deduce what is needed to bypass the screening.  Further, there is no process defined whereby an honest citizen can get any erroneous information corrected.

Also, there is no system to ensure recompense to an individual unjustly denied boarding.

This system will not work.  It must not be implemented.  

This program is an aggregious affront to the Constitutition of the United States of America--that same constitution you swore an oath to support and defend.

For the record, I am an honorably discharged officer of the USAF.  I fully recognize the need to identify and apprehend potential terrorists. But CAPPS II is not the solution.  It must not be allowed to be implemented.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Peter G. Capek
Comment:
The proposed system is founded on inadequate and bad science, is a severe risk to personal security, safety and privacy, and is a
large step in the wrong direction for a country which is founded on, and claims still to believe in, personal freedoms.

In a perfect world, such a system might not have significant risks.   But that is not our world, and there is a large body of experience and example where such systems have caused considerable harm, been the source of dis- and misinformation, and generally not fulfilled the claims of their advocates.

A system such as proposed has no clear, or even believable, basis for stopping terrorism.  A person whose intent is to commit a
terrorist act can easily behave in a way which is well within norms and thereby evade detection.   There is no evidence whatsoever
to the contrary.  Yet, a secret system, one which is invisible and not subject to audit and examination by the public and the individuals it describes is subject to abuse, inaccuracy, creep and broadening of its stated objectives.   In addition, it will likely have a
significant direct cost, significant related costs on law enforcement and transportation companies, for (at the very best) unclear benefit.   Further, it is a step along a slippery slope which will make the next step seem a little less silly; I'd rather we didn't take the first step.

It is not appropriate, desirable, or reasonable to eliminate all scrutiny, risk assessment and notification, and Privacy Act (1974) controls from such a system, if it were to be built.   I would strongly prefer that it not be built, that CAPPS I be dismantled, and that
occasional random searches be the primary means of assuring air travel safety.


The proposed rules and system will not help security, are expensive and subject to abuse, error-prone, and lack sufficient public visibility and public scrutiny.   They should NOT be enacted.

I want my government to be accountable.



Shrouding government actions in secrecy, by eliminating accountability, is abhorent to all thinking citizens.



The data in the underlying systems will be used by the government to make decisions affecting individuals.  The ability to review and correct alleged facts used by the government to make such decisions is important to all citizens, not just the affected individuals.



Recently published reports have shown that comercial databases of consumer information subject to the Fair Credit Reporting Act have erroneous "facts" in 70% of the files.  These are errors.  The FCIR allows these to be discovered and corrected, to the benefit of both the customer and also the subject of such erroneous information.



If the DOT (or any government agency) creates a system without such elemental safeguards, then much of the data will be unreliable, and hence a waste of taxpayer dollars.  If such an agency relies upon commercial databases for input, then the presumption that that only true facts are in the government database is void.  This means that the government files will probably be even less reliable, since the facts gathered from non-commercial sources would not be discoverable nor correctable.



Also, if a citizen uses the FCIR to correct errors in his commercial credit files, there should be a guarantee that those corrections are reflected in the government databases in a timely manner.



Without the accountability provided by the Privacy Act, tax dollars would be wasted, government [agents] will make bad decisions, and innocent citizens will suffer the results of those bad decisions.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Tom Hicks
Comment:
The CAPPS II program is a dangerously misguided effort and
should be immediately abolished. It subverts the intent
of the Constitution and invades the privacy to which
American citizens are entitled by that great document.

Instead of attempting to foolishly identify "possible
terrorists" based on vague and ill-defined personal data,
law enforcement agencies should be concentrating their
resources on identifying exactly who, in the airport,
IS a terrorist. The Israelis have been successfully
doing this for decades.

The CAPPS II program is not only un-Constitutional but
will simply not work. It is too easily subverted, as
illustrated by this MIT research paper:

http://www.swiss.ai.mit.edu/6805/student-papers/spring02-
papers/caps.htm

I urge you to remember the oath you swore to uphold the
Constitution of the United States, and to work toward
dismantling this mis-guided program immediately.
    sincerely yours,
    Tom Hicks
    M.S. Computer Science

p.s. I will be boycotting Delta airlines in the future
because of their over-eager cooperation with this
dangerous program.

The CAPPS program is an offense to every ideal of American democracy.  For those who value their privacy and right-thinking people who know that invasions of privacy do not ensure safety (and in fact jeopardize the safety of democracy itself) air travel will become an undesirable means of transportation.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Donna E. Truax
Comment:
March 16, 2003 

Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-401 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  The proposal to exempt such a potentially broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.

My family has been directly affected by identity theft. This is a real and all too common problem. Unauthorized access to databases is a well-publicized occurrence. This is not only an invasion of privacy; there is also significant risk that the information cannot be guaranteed safe and accurate.

The data used to makes these assessments is broad and subject to error. There is little explanation as to how this data will be effective in providing greater security while it is clear that it is an invasion of privacy. In addition, there is no opportunity for those directly affected by these assessments to view the information, correct false information, or rectify the situation if categorized as unsafe. The data would be subject to exposure through hacking, and persons could be harmed by false information created by identity theft or intentional misinformation. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,
Donna Truax

Title: Emese Papp
Comment: Having lived under Communism it is this sort of division, a division among those that should be allied in loyalty and respect for the government, and for their values that the delta screening propogates -- i am outraged that i have emigrated here and now this country is becoming the very thing that it states it is not--- NO spying on your own, no violation of rights and most importantly no discrimination !!!!! how dare we not be allowed to fly if we have poor credit especially since 60% of the american population today has bad credit and if we have credit fraud-- this is outrageous what sort of greater division between the classes this will bring and exemplify the sort of fear that it is to feel under the communist regime.  thank you and i hope you have not only listened but also tried to understand this will not happen here and believe this because it is true!!!!!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Anthony R. Adams, Captain, USCG (Ret.)
Comment:
Dear Admiral Loy (Jim), Pat and I are shocked and surprised that you would support and/or sponsor such an irrational and flagrant invasion of privacy.  Surely you must know that once personal data is brought onto the Internet, it is available to all who seek it.  There is no true security of information once it enters cyberspace.  Don't get sucked into the politically correct avoidance of passenger profiling.  You know where the bulk of the terrorists originate; and, it is not the 80 year old lady in a wheel chair--but, you will invade her privacy by checking her credit history (finding her in arrears in her rent during the Great Depression) and her criminal record (like the time when she was arrested during an anti-Vietnam War rally).  

You, more than most of the Congress and much of the Administration, know that our men and women of the armed forces have fought, and died, and are fighting, and dying, to defend our liberties.  Among the most important of those liberties is personal privacy.

Don't cast a net of suspicion over the entire flying public.  If this program continues, the Lord only knows where it will stop.

Please think about it.

Respectfully,

Tony & Pat Adams


Please think about it!!!!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Guynn Prince
Comment:
March 10, 2003 

Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-401 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  The proposal to exempt such a potentially broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties  without increasing security or making the public safer.

By exempting all risk assessment reports and the information contained in those reports, this third notice suffers from the same defects as the previous two notices published in the Federal Register.  Exempting risk assessment reports and the information that populates them would remove accountability to the individual.  Individuals would not be allowed to access the information contained about them, nor would they be notified if files were being kept on them or her. This is very serious in light of the fact that investigatory material could be included in these reports  without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 

Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals  the very thing the Privacy Act was passed to prevent. 

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Guynn Prince


OST-1996-1437 - Withdraw proposed rule.

Title: Richard D. Foley
Comment: I am opposed to the proposed Computer Assisted Passenger Pre-Screening System for two factors: (1)  It has no built in checks and balances, or the ability for a citizen to review and correct errors as provided in the Privacy Act of 1974 (2)  It is a huge boondoggle incapable of ever delivering what it promises at a catastrophic cost to the civil liberties of the citizenry of this nation.  At its foundation it is an irrational concept doomed by its very nature to result in massive staggering failure.

Title: George Peck
Comment:
If pawing through my personal belongings, feeling me up and down like a schoolgirl, and tearing apart every piece of may laptop computer isn't enough, you're now discussing CAPPS II as a precursor to getting on public transportation. The country that imagined this kind of fiasco in fiction only a few years ago seems to be accepting with open arms now. Well, not this resident of the country.

Despite Admiral Loy's assurances that 'your privacy is important to us' (and, the last time I checked, privacy wasn't foremost in the military's mind, so I don't trust an "admiral's" privacy promises for a nanosecond), every appearance of the details of this system that have squeaked out appear to fly in the face of this countries traditional of personal liberty and privacy.

Quite simply: CAPPS II is a horrible idea. Stop it before it gets started.
