Title: Kathleen A. Clark
Comment:
The epitome of freedom is the freedom to travel.  Development of a program that bans people who have not been charged with any crime from travelling and intrudes upon the privacy of the multi-millions of totally innocent, upstanding Americans in the process is an outrage.  The developers of this program have taken their cues not from our Founding Fathers but from the Nazis and the Communists. This propounders of this program are traitors to the Freedom and the Constitution.   Americans are not going to tolerate this.  They are going to quit flying except out of necessity.   There is no excuse for the overreaching nature of this program.   I urge it be scrapped.  A narrow screen against names on the terrorist watch list is justified -- no more.  


Protest against color coded security "passes" for airline travel

Title: L.J. Wallace
Comment:
Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  The proposal to exempt such a potentially broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.
By exempting all risk assessment reports and the information contained in those reports, this third notice suffers from the same defects as the previous two notices published in the Federal Register.  Exempting risk assessment reports and the information that populates them would remove accountability to the individual.  Individuals would not be allowed to access the information contained about them, nor would they be notified if files were being kept on them. This is very serious in light of the fact that investigatory material could be included in these reports -- without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 
Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals -- the very thing the Privacy Act was passed to prevent. 
Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

L James Wallace

Title: Sarah A. Stang
Comment: Please withdraw this proposal.  It does not protect our privacy.  We need less government interference, not more.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, SIPB
Comment:
I am writing to convey my strong opposition to the Department of
Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information
contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act 1974.  By mining large
amounts of information about every passenger, and not allowing passengers 
any means to ensure the correctness of such information, the proposed rule
risks creating a permanent underclass who would always be subjected to
intrusive searches or even denied the right to travel freely.  The very idea
of a government bureaucracy that routinely maintains secret files on
individuals who have never committed any crime is anathema to a free society.
This Orwellian intrusion on individual privacy is the very injustice that the
Privacy Act was aimed at preventing.  It seems the height of underhandedness
for a federal agency to attempt to create such a system by means of executive
rule-making when a similar proposal, the Total Information Awareness system,
was so recently soundly defeated in Congress.  At the very least, such a 
profound curtailment of privacy rights deserves more visible, legislative
debate.  For all these reasons, the proposed rule should be withdrawn.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: United States Citizen
Comment:
I am a US Army veteran, and have a father who is currently deployed in Kuwait with his US Army Reserve unit, so I know very well what the word patriotism means.  I feel very strongly about protecting the country and it's citizens, but the recent news about the personal threat level database which has come to light today on CNN I find very disturbing.  I think this recent intrusion into peoples privacy is crossing the line.  Furthermore I find it and insult as a veteran that the very freedoms that I gave up part of my life and swore to protect are the very ones that the government seems hell bent on taking away from the citizens.  I feel that the whole reason that this country exists is to defend and protect those freedoms and show the world what democracy and freedom is.  I feel that the personal freedoms of the people of the United States need to be protected above all else, for that is the very heart of what makes this nation great. THIS IS NOT THE WAY TO PROTECT THOSE FREEDOMS!!!

The government is out of line checking the background of every citizen who flies on a plane.  This is only going to lead to people being marked and targeted needlessly and more of our personal freedoms being lost.  What is next, security checks for traveling on a train, or owning a car?   Is the government protecting us from those that would attack our freedoms and way of life, protecting us from ourselves, or becoming the very attacker of the freedoms for which it stands?

It is not the right of the government to target it's own when it has enough problems as it is keeping people out of our borders.  There is no reason that the government should be casting such a wide net amongst it's civilian population trying to catch just a few people that should never have gotten inside our borders to begin with.  To say that I am outraged with the current path that the government is undertaking domestically would be an understatement.  I do not always agree with the actions of the government, but I am very much a patriot, and I believe in exercising my personal rights and freedoms so as not to loose them.

I implore you to act against this gross threat to our freedoms and never forget that the government serves the people, not the other way around.  Serve the people and the people will always back you.  Go forward with this and the airlines will be bankrupted one at a time by the great citizens of this nation.

Respectfully,

A United States Citizen
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Howard Sheffer
Comment:
This is to voice my concern about CAPPS II.  Why must the average citizen be subjected to violations of their privacy in order to try to derail terrorists?  There was ample information on all of the 9/11 terrorists to get most of them if only the information was applied.  This new scheme does nothing to catch new terrorists.  They have had ample time to cover their tracks now.  Exatracting a citizens private information and having it available to ANY agency will not help in catching terrorists.  It will however open ordinary peoples records to abuse as has happened in the past when records are made available.
Howard A. Sheffer
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: James P. Rife
Comment: Dear Sir:  As  a business traveler, I am writing to voice my outrage over TSA's Orwellian pilot CAPPS II program, which in my opinion is a gross violation of my privacy and civil rights.  While I fully support the war on terrorism and understand that reasonable security measures must be implemented to keep terrorists off our airplanes, I cannot stomach the TSA proposed requirement that airlines with which I may fly must run a credit check on me, investigate my banking history (complete with checking and savings account number disclosures), and run a criminal background check on me.  According to written news accounts, all of the information gathered will be stored for fifty (50!) years on computers that may or may not be safe from malicious hackers out to steal my identity.  Furthermore, every time an airline runs a credit report on me under the program, my credit rating will suffer.  In short, my private financial and personal information is none of the airline's business nor that of the TSA.  I understand that Delta is currently the only airline involved in the pilot CAPPS program.  Consequently, I will most definitely not be flying Delta. Should the program expand to include other airlines, then I will be taking the train or bus or simply driving myself rather than submit to this kind of invasive questioning. Sincerely, James P. Rife
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Joshua Muskovitz
Comment:
Please abandon the CAPPS II project.  Respected academics have already produced research demonstating how CAPPS II can be defeated.  Continuing the project in this light forces a flawed system on the American people, one that will reduce, not enhance, their actual security, while also intruding into their private lives unnecessarily.


Please discontinue the CAPPS II pilot program.

Title: Samer S. Farha
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  The proposal to exempt such a potentially broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.

By exempting all risk assessment reports and the information contained in those reports, this third notice suffers from the same defects as the previous two notices published in the Federal Register.  Exempting risk assessment reports and the information that populates them would remove accountability to the individual.  Individuals would not be allowed to access the information contained about them, nor would they be notified if files were being kept on them. This is very serious in light of the fact that investigatory material could be included in these reports -- without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 

Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals -- the very thing the Privacy Act was passed to prevent. 

Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about almost every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely,

Samer S Farha

Title: Robert Dixon
Comment: We have read about the CAPPS II program and are outraged.  Everyone wants safety but there is no such thing as complete safety.  We are not willing to give up the rights so many of us have fought and died for.  We support the security measures adopted after 9/11 but this new program goes to far.  Please kill this pilot with Delta and the program altogether.  It will not work.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Karen Parsons
Comment: I am writing in regards to the new CAPPS II program. I work for a major west coast air carrier so I am out there on the front lines at the airport, assisting in making my workplace and aircraft safe. I have worked as a GSC (ground security clearance agent). While I feel that we need to make our skies safer checking credit reports and financial info on our passengers doesn't accomplish this. TSA is asking to review way to much personal/fiancial data just so I can go to Disneyland. I feel this behind the scenes search is VERY invasive to my/our personal privacy and is extreme. I understand, at this point, that supposedly on a few TSA people would see this info, who knows who else could get access to this database and do so many other things with the information gathered therein. Its hard enough to keep an eye on your own personal credit report and try to correct those let alone trying to clarify info in a federal database. Please reassess how we are going to make the skies safer.

Title: UC Berkeley, Political Science Department
Comment:
I write you to express opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  This proposal would exempt such a potentially broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act as to eviscerate the protections placed there by the Acts authors.  Personal privacy and civil liberties, values which have been long respected in this country, would be violated and eroded by the Computer Assisted Passenger Pre-Screening (CAPPS) II systems storing information about every airline traveler.  Whats more is that this massive information gathering and storage scheme will do nothing to increase security on airplanes and in airports or to make the public at large safer.

By exempting all risk assessment reports and the information contained in those reports, this third notice suffers from the same defects as the previous two notices published in the Federal Register.  Exempting risk assessment reports and the information that populates them would remove accountability to the individual.  Individuals would not be allowed to access the information contained about them, nor would they be notified if files were being kept on them. This is very serious in light of the fact that investigatory material could be included in these reports  without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 

Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals  the very thing the Privacy Act was passed to prevent.  Such a travesty of our national traditions and heritage should not be pushed on the people of this country.

At this time, when other proposed surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate.  No one wants to be watched, especially when no good can come from it.

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your attention and responsiveness.
Sincerely,
Bradley Herman

Title: Edward M. Goff
Comment: Dear Admiral Loy,As an American citizen I am discusted with the whole idea of CAPPS II.Our personal information is just that! I am sickened at this Administration and their attacks on our civil liberties, CAPPS II just being one of the latest examples.I believe in our Constitution and disagree with the idea that suspecting every American who flys to be a terrorist until proven innocent. Old women having to hand over their nail files, people being strip searched and the like. Now the government wants to check our credit etc. in order for us to board a plane ?--I think not!! I have written Delta Airlines, who seems very interested in CAPPS II as policy for their airline. I have let them know that I am boycotting them until they make it clear that they will not go further with this latest attack on our rights.Do we need safe travel? Yes, we do! Do we need to treat Americans like terrorists to secure ourselves? No!Thank you for your consideration. A free American,so far, Martin Goff
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Adam Olenn
Comment:
I am writing to protest the development of the CAPPS II system for airport screening.  This program is a well-intentioned but horribly misguided attempt to protect Americans.  It is important for us to remember that to violate Americans' freedoms is to kill America.  I am a patriot, but if we throw away the constitution, we have nothing left to defend.  Please recall Benjamin Franklins comment that those who would exchange essential liberties
for a little temporary security deserve neither.

I do not fear terrorists on a plane.  I know that I and my fellow citizens would happily make an example of anyone attempting a stunt like 9/11.  I *DO* fear being unreasonably searched every time I travel.

Please demonstrate your love and respect of America and its founding ideals by raising your voice and your votes against the CAPPS II system.

Thank you, and God bless America.


Adam

Title: Jesus Gonzalez
Comment:
March 10, 2003 

Documentary Services Division 
Attention: Docket Section, Room PL-401 
Docket No. OST-1996-1437 
Department of Transportation, SVC-124 
Washington, DC 20590 

Dear Director, 

I am writing to express my opposition to the Department of Transportation's proposed exemption of risk assessments and the information contained in those assessments from the Privacy Act of 1974.  The proposal to exempt such a potentially broad and vaguely-defined system of records from the Privacy Act eviscerates the Privacy Act's protections. By storing massive amounts of information about every air traveler, this system would violate privacy and erode other civil liberties -- without increasing security or making the public safer.
By exempting all risk assessment reports and the information contained in those reports, this third notice suffers from the same defects as the previous two notices published in the Federal Register.  Exempting risk assessment reports and the information that populates them would remove accountability to the individual.  Individuals would not be allowed to access the information contained about them, nor would they be notified if files were being kept on them. This is very serious in light of the fact that investigatory material could be included in these reports -- without providing any mechanism for the individual to see if the information is correct; and that categories of sources of information would also be kept secret from the individual. 
Even though the Privacy Act does allow for exemptions to protect national security and to help law enforcement, the exemptions that the DoT envisions are far too broad and allow the creation of large secret files on individuals -- the very thing the Privacy Act was passed to prevent. 
Finally, at a time when other surveillance systems such as the Total Information Awareness Program are coming under heavy scrutiny by Congress, a rule such as this, governing the collection, storage, and disclosure of sensitive personal information about virtually every US citizen, should be exposed to a much wider discussion and debate. 

For these reasons the proposed rule should be withdrawn. 

Thank you for your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns. 

Sincerely, Jesus Gonzalez
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Heather Dimon
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern:
 
I am writing as a citizen who as flown on Delta Airlines in the past year, to express my views on the CAPPS II (Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System) program. I am appalled that the US Government is working with Delta to test this system, which I feel is in violation of US citizens' rights to personal privacy. Delta has no right to conduct background checks, obtain personal banking records and run credit checks on passengers in the name of "security." I also understand that those passengers given a threat asessment color of "Red" will not be allowed to fly.
 
How exactly are these threat assesments to be determined? How can you insure the safety of citizen's private banking, credit and other information Delta has gathered? How to you justify hurting people's credit rating by running additional credit reports on them? 
 
Additionally, I would like to know exactly how it was determined that this information will show definitively that a person poses a security risk; and why a person should be penalized by not being allowed to fly on your airline based on that information. I was under the impression that in the United States of America all citizens are innocent until proven guilty. 
 
Until Delta has officially stops using the the CAPPS II (Computer Assisted Passenger Prescreening System) program I will no longer fly on this airline. I will be asking all my friends and relatives to join me in boycotting your airline. I am also sending letters to my congressmen regarding my views on this policy.
 
Please let me know what your intentions are in continuing this policy.
 
Sincerely,
Heather Dimon

Title: Brent E. Lancaster
Comment:
As a frequent traveller, I am writing to urge you to stop the CAPPS II program. I am deeply concerned that this program will create a permanent blacklist of Americans who cannot travel freely, and hinder the security at our nation's airports.

I have read that people have already been stopped and banned from flying under initial government "no fly" lists and have been unable to clear their names, getting caught up in the federal bureaucracy.  This national system would only increase the delays and blacklist even more innocent Americans. Innocent people could be blocked or delayed in their travel for work and vacations based on mistakes, errors and false leads.

Given the chaos American airports will experience, actual terrorist threats will be harder to detect.  Terrorists will learn how to game the system by using false background information.  And the constant false alarms might divert the attention of airport security officers who - through training and experience - could detect actual threats.

If adopted, this system will use government and private companies' databases to build a profile of each passenger.  The compiled information could include credit history, travel history, housing information, membership in different organizations, employment records, and other personal information. Not only will this system be a tempting targets for hackers, but will also be prone to abuse by government and airline employees. 

Once again, I urge you to oppose this invasive and untrustworthy system.  

I look forward to hearing from you on this important matter.


Respectfully,

Brent E Lancaster
Corporate Meeting Manager & Frequent Flyer and current boycotter of Delta Air Lines, Inc.

Title: Jeffrey R. McNamee
Comment: I vehemently oppose the CAPPS II program.  First and foremost, this program poses grave danger to our system of privacy in this country.  It has been almost cliche to trounce on civil liberties since 9/11/01.  However, this is ridiculous.  I see no reason why this program has to exist, including national security.  Setting up a definitive system for determining risk is simply not effective.  Random searches are the most effective and the least predictable.  The CAPPS II system could easily be beaten and will simply hurt innocent people's lives in the doing.  Credit reporting is far from perfect and it would take nearly 100% accuracy for this system to be remotely legitimate.  Your administration (TSA) is simply taking this "security" system a little too far and is making the United States look like 1940s Germany when it comes to not trusting its own citizens.  Let's be realistic and stop painting rosy pictures about the life we could have with this.  Sacrifice freedom for security and you get neither.  We are not, and will not be, any safer today than we will with this system.  You have set yourself up for political ruin.

Regarding implementation of the CAPPSII system:  In this time of high stress for all Americans, and especially for the travel industry, I'm sure you are trying to do the right thing for travellers and for our country. In testing and implementing the CAPPS II program, you are undermining the freedom of our nation and threatening the financial security of the airline industry. Title: Monica C. Way
Comment:
This main flaw of CAPS; the fact that individuals know their CAPS status, enables the system to be reverse engineered and therefore will prove to undermine the system drastically. You know if youre carryons have been manually inspected. You know if youve been questioned. You know if youre asked to stand in a special line. You know if youve been frisked. All of this open scrutiny makes it possible to learn an anti-profile to defeat CAPS, even if the profile itself is always kept secret. We call this the Carnival Booth Effect since, like a carnival, it entices terrorists to Step Right Up! See if youre a winner! In this case, the terrorist can step right up and see if hes been flagged  and therefore he can quite easily and simply find ways around this screening process.  And then who gets frightened and gets their privacy invaded?  The millions of passengers every year who may fit a specific description or have an Arab-sounding name...this is dangerous and illegal!!!

Thank you.

Title: Gail C. Schwartzer
Comment:
RE: CAPPS II

     I think this is one of the most horrific and Orwellian ideas yet.   The Patriot Act shredded at least 4 of our basic rights, wiping out due process, right to counsel, biased juries, drawn-out trials, as well as the 4th Amendment.    This shreds the 4th amendment and the right to privacy and treats all Americans as suspects.  Indeed, one can get on this list inadvertently and has incorrectly --- and they have no way to correct the situation -- there is no due process --- only the wall that it's top priority or secret.   I've never heard of anything so insulting.   Indeed I assure you more people would be banging on your doors were this properly debated and presented to the public to analyse.   Wake up and realize we prefer our rights to your intrusion on our privacy and lives.   I would like to discuss some reasonable ways to protect us from terrorists and can't do so in this space.   Sincerely yours, 
Gail C. Schwartzer

Title: Bruce Tribbensee
Comment: Please stop supporting the CAPPS program. It just goes too far. The government shouldn't be storing information about innocent Americans. Especially credit and travel information. This program is just not dealing with the right issues.

Title: Kirsten E. Dierking
Comment:
The CAPPS II system will not solve the problems of air security, but will only shift the focus of terrorists to change their tack.  Screening everyone, especially with the wealth of information that has been gathered commercially on every consumer, instead of actually tracking down terrorists and dealing with problems like identity theft tells me and many americans that this is not here to help us, but to control us.  The motive to create a system like this I believe to be inspired by fear and laziness.  Fear that we are under constant attack, and laziness in trying to find a real solution.  Concentrate your efforts on the holes that were exposed in the security system during the 9/11 attacks instead of trying to use the Big Brother approach to scare us all to death and control us all to death.  Things like this make me glad that I'm not a black american, or a foreigner of any kind.  You are creating a country where everyone is guilty until proven innocent.  Wasn't that the opposite of what our founding fathers wanted?  Wake up and smell the coffee, because I can tell you that the average american is certainly waking up to what is going on here and they do NOT like it!

Thank you,

-kirsten dierking
kirhome1@comcast.net

Title: Andrew W. Sharp
Comment:
You may like to take note of the following CRS problem which is becoming an issue in Europe.
Anti-discrimination rules are being taken to mean that the same flat charge has to be applied to all tickets. This is OK for air tickets, but when a rail ticket is issued as part of an air journey, this causes problems. The rail sector has a much lower fare than the air sector, and cannot stand the typical GDS charge. Consider Chicago - Newark - New York Penn, where the Newark - New York sector costs under $12. A standard GDS charge, plus commission, BSP charge and credit card charge leaves very little for New Jersey Transit!
Clarification that equal charges must be made for equal services would help - typically, on airport railways, no reservation is required (or possible), so less work is required by the GDS. Therefore the charge could legitimately be lower than an air journey - or even an Acela journey - where a reservation IS required.


A problem in Europe is that anti-discrimination requirements are read to mean that the same flat charge has to be made for each ticket issued. This is fine for high-fare air journeys, but not for low-fare rail journeys as part of an air journey (Chicago - Newark - New York). Typically reservations are not required on rail journeys, so the same charge ought not to be required. This needs to be made explicit and clarified.

Title: Janice Feroy
Comment:
My name is Janice Feroy, and I work for Select Travel American Express in Federal Way, WA.  We employ 10 people, were established in 1986,  and sell travel to both corporate and leisure travelers.   

With respect to proposed CRS rules , these regulations, if finalized as written, will harm competition in general, and consumers in particular.  In addition, they will likely harm my business directly, since these misguided rules will let airlines control all public access to airfares, eliminating my ability to give my customers access to the best airfares and services.  The rules also prevent CRSs from providing me with financial incentives  the federal government should not interfere with my right to negotiate such assistance.

The bottom line is that, so long as airlines own or maintain control over ticket distributors like Amadeus, Worldspan and Orbitz, federal oversight is vital to preserving fair competition.  With this in mind, I strongly urge the U.S. Department of Transportation to ensure that any new CRS rules adopted include the following provisions:

§	Retain flexibility in CRS commercial agreements with travel agencies
§	Continue Mandatory Participation and extend to cover airlines maintaining marketing agreements with CRSs to ensure consumer safeguards equally apply to all airline-controlled distributors, including Orbitz; and, 
§	Apply existing and proposed CRS rules to Orbitz, which operates as a CRS today. 

In addition, I strongly support the U.S. DOTs recent proposal to extend the current CRS rules through January 2004, to allow thorough review and enable new industry programs to succeed in the marketplace. 

Thank you for this opportunity to share my comments.

Title: Alitalia - Line Aeree Italiane SpA
Comment:
Comments of Alitalia on New Proposed Rule Making  MIDT

Alitalia - Linee Aeree Italiane SPA (Alitalia) hereby respectfully submits its comments on the New Proposed Rule Making (NPRM), published in the Federal Register on November 15, 2002 on the issue concerning changes to MIDT data. 

As indicated proposed changes imply:
1. removing the travel agency identification from marketing data in the US market, unless the carrier buying the data participates in the segment
2. the carrier can request that Global Distribution Systems (GDSs) exclude their data from an MIDT product.

Alitalia is against modifying the MIDT product as presently released and strongly opposes the Departments proposal.

MIDT is a valuable source of marketing and booking information supporting the overall strategic business processes of  the Company. 
Alliances and Strategies, Strategic Marketing, Network Management and Sales departments rely on the data provided by MIDT for  analysis, forecasts and decisions. 
In order to provide top quality support to business requirements analysis and decisions,  Alitalia has invested millions of dollars for the implementation of our commercial systems which enable us to process this data and produce relevant reports.

The proposed changes will
1. massively impact on the Company commercial systems currently in use with immediate effect
2. undermine the whole business process of Strategic Marketing and Network Management  in the short and medium  term. 

Therefore Alitalia will face the loss of potential future revenue, the loss of relevant economic investments, as well as the loss of high quality information for commercial and planning activities.

Alitalia expresses its  serious concern on the negative impacts that restrictions on MIDT information has on its business and cannot perceive any benefit for the balance of competitive environment that such change is expected to establish.

In summary, Alitalia believes there is no evidence of carriers misusing MIDT data, on the contrary, this data enables carriers to improve commercial strategies and planning in order to customise services, offer better prices, increase profitability and efficiency by meeting demands of marketplace for both customers and travel agents. 
Transparency on information promotes competition and marketplace functions more efficiently when interested parties can access information about supply and demand chain. 

Alitalia strongly urges the Department to consider the heavy impacts that the proposal has on our Companys business processes with associate consequent difficulty in finding alternative solutions at an acceptable cost, giving the economic state of the airline industry.

Title: Association of Corporate Travel Executives
Comment:
Writing on behalf of the airlines most significant customer base, business travelers and the companies which fund their trips, I am compelled to advise you that the proposed changes to the rules governing the use of Computer Reservation's Systems represent a major reversal of every hard-fought consumer protection clause in the current regulations. Not only will they frustrate current attempts to reach a long-term solution to the airlines' problems, they will further encourage corporations to seek alternatives to flying.

1) The airlines maintain the proposed changes will lower distribution costs, and (by inference) airfares. Considering the financial status of the nation's carriers, this commitment to discounting travel seems unrealistic at this time.

2) Removing the regulation that that airlines must provide equal access to all fares offered on the CRS will drive up cost in three ways:
By opening the door to CRS/airfare bias
By deliberately complicating the airfare search process (driving up process time)
By virtually requiring corporations or travel agencies to subscribe to multiple CRS systems

3) The proposed changes will require the introduction of entirely new process for corporate travel departments and their agencies. The expense of retrofitting and retraining will ultimately come out of existing travel budgets.

4) The proposed changes introduce an additional annual negotiation between carriers and CRS subscribers.

5) The benefits associated with the dangled carrot of greater Web fare accessibility (long sought after by business travel managers) are offset by competitive safeguards that would now be lost under the proposed changes. 

I regret that there is no silver-lining in the CRS rule changes as proposed: not for business travelers, not for their corporations, nor for the airlines. I respectfully suggest that the Department of Transportation abandon these changes in pursuit of realistic long-term changes, with mutual benefits, that encourages business travel and a healthier economic environment for the transportation industry.

Sincerely,

Mark A. Williams
President
Association of Corporate Travel Executives

Title: Mercatus Center, George Mason University
Comment:
The DOT proposals presume that the systems have market power over the airlines and travel agencies. Our analysis, on the other hand, suggests that the intense competition in the travel agency business coupled with the emergence of system alternatives is likely to have a counter-balancing effect on any alleged market power. Given thin profit margins, large numbers of incumbents, and low barriers to entry, travel agencies remain extremely alert to any innovation that would benefit their customers.  This alertness  gives the agencies a degree of bargaining power against the systems and airlines since both need travel agencies for bookings. 

 

DOT, in revisiting these regulations, seems disposed to lifting previous encumbrances on the air travel industry, though in only a piecemeal fashion.  The ability to effectively regulate prices and contract terms¿as DOT has concluded in several places and as we have endeavored to point out above¿is at best ineffective (as industry participants innovate along non-regulated margins), and at worst counterproductive (as costs are raised and air travel is thereby made less attractive).  It may prove easier, and far less socially costly, therefore, simply to allow the CRS rules to sunset.

Title: Walter G. Gay
Comment:
By attempting to open up the field for competition with the CRS to Airline relationship, the DOT rulings potentially eliminate the opportunity for travel agency owners (over 20,000 businesses nationwide), to negotiate favorable terms with ANY CRS provider, especially those travel agencies located in a "hub" airline market.

What these rules will also accomplish is that competition and unbiased information WILL BE ELIMINATED for the travelling public by way of their local travel agency.  DEALERSHIPS will be created with agencies supporting those airline companies that offer the best deal, while virtually eliminating the small travel agency that will not have the ability to negotiate with any airline supplier, due to their small sales.

There are changes that need to be made with the current distribution system, however, the majority of the rules that are being proposed will have a long-term, negative effect on small businesses and the ability of the travelling public to receive fair, unbiased information with respect to airline travel.

The only logical answer to the rules that are being proposed, must be NO.

Title: Cindy L. Heston
Comment:
I am the Corporate Travel Manager for Thomson (manufacture of RCA and GE consumer electronics products, and owner of Technicolor). I am against the proposed CRS rules change, as it will dilute the opportunity for the managed travel program to leverage policies and commitments for corporate airline discounts. In essence by not requiring the airlines to publish ALL of their pricing in one or more central databases we will have every airline hustleling their prices through their own individual applications, and there will be no way to centralize the information for fair market comparisons. Eliminating the GDS's will not help the airlines (it will even make them more reflexive on price) and will only hurt consumers and major businesses that are already gauged by airline pricing.

Please feel free to contact me directly for further comments on this issue

Title: Mercatus Center, George Mason University
Comment:
The DOT proposals presume that the systems have market power over the airlines and travel agencies. Our analysis, on the other hand, suggests that the intense competition in the travel agency business coupled with the emergence of system alternatives is likely to have a counter-balancing effect on any alleged market power. Given thin profit margins, large numbers of incumbents, and low barriers to entry, travel agencies remain extremely alert to any innovation that would benefit their customers.  This alertness  gives the agencies a degree of bargaining power against the systems and airlines since both need travel agencies for bookings. 

 

DOT, in revisiting these regulations, seems disposed to lifting previous encumbrances on the air travel industry, though in only a piecemeal fashion.  The ability to effectively regulate prices and contract terms¿as DOT has concluded in several places and as we have endeavored to point out above¿is at best ineffective (as industry participants innovate along non-regulated margins), and at worst counterproductive (as costs are raised and air travel is thereby made less attractive).  It may prove easier, and far less socially costly, therefore, simply to allow the CRS rules to sunset.

Title: Alitalia - Line Aeree Italiane SpA
Comment:
Comments of Alitalia on New Proposed Rule Making  MIDT

Alitalia - Linee Aeree Italiane SPA (Alitalia) hereby respectfully submits its comments on the New Proposed Rule Making (NPRM), published in the Federal Register on November 15, 2002 on the issue concerning changes to MIDT data. 

As indicated proposed changes imply:
1. removing the travel agency identification from marketing data in the US market, unless the carrier buying the data participates in the segment
2. the carrier can request that Global Distribution Systems (GDSs) exclude their data from an MIDT product.

Alitalia is against modifying the MIDT product as presently released and strongly opposes the Departments proposal.

MIDT is a valuable source of marketing and booking information supporting the overall strategic business processes of  the Company. 
Alliances and Strategies, Strategic Marketing, Network Management and Sales departments rely on the data provided by MIDT for  analysis, forecasts and decisions. 
In order to provide top quality support to business requirements analysis and decisions,  Alitalia has invested millions of dollars for the implementation of our commercial systems which enable us to process this data and produce relevant reports.

The proposed changes will
1. massively impact on the Company commercial systems currently in use with immediate effect
2. undermine the whole business process of Strategic Marketing and Network Management  in the short and medium  term. 

Therefore Alitalia will face the loss of potential future revenue, the loss of relevant economic investments, as well as the loss of high quality information for commercial and planning activities.

Alitalia expresses its  serious concern on the negative impacts that restrictions on MIDT information has on its business and cannot perceive any benefit for the balance of competitive environment that such change is expected to establish.

In summary, Alitalia believes there is no evidence of carriers misusing MIDT data, on the contrary, this data enables carriers to improve commercial strategies and planning in order to customise services, offer better prices, increase profitability and efficiency by meeting demands of marketplace for both customers and travel agents. 
Transparency on information promotes competition and marketplace functions more efficiently when interested parties can access information about supply and demand chain. 

Alitalia strongly urges the Department to consider the heavy impacts that the proposal has on our Companys business processes with associate consequent difficulty in finding alternative solutions at an acceptable cost, giving the economic state of the airline industry.

Title: Mercatus Center, George Mason University
Comment:
The DOT proposals presume that the systems have market power over the airlines and travel agencies. Our analysis, on the other hand, suggests that the intense competition in the travel agency business coupled with the emergence of system alternatives is likely to have a counter-balancing effect on any alleged market power. Given thin profit margins, large numbers of incumbents, and low barriers to entry, travel agencies remain extremely alert to any innovation that would benefit their customers.  This alertness  gives the agencies a degree of bargaining power against the systems and airlines since both need travel agencies for bookings. 

 

DOT, in revisiting these regulations, seems disposed to lifting previous encumbrances on the air travel industry, though in only a piecemeal fashion.  The ability to effectively regulate prices and contract terms¿as DOT has concluded in several places and as we have endeavored to point out above¿is at best ineffective (as industry participants innovate along non-regulated margins), and at worst counterproductive (as costs are raised and air travel is thereby made less attractive).  It may prove easier, and far less socially costly, therefore, simply to allow the CRS rules to sunset.

Title: George Mason University, Mercatus Center
Comment: The Regulatory Studies Program (RSP) of the Mercatus Center at George Mason University is dedicated to advancing knowledge of the impact of regulation on society. As part of its mission, RSP conducts careful and independent analyses employing contemporary economic scholarship to assess rulemaking proposals from the perspective of the public interest.  Thus, this comment on the Computer Reservation Systems does not represent the views of any particular affected party or special interest group, but is designed to evaluate the effect of the Agency¿s proposals on overall consumer welfare.

Title: Dan Moore
Comment: Air carriers should be required to track and maintain accurate records of the causes for delay.  This doesn't have to be overly cumbersome and bureaucratic, and can be implemented in a year or two when the industry recovers.  Airlines are not trusted to "tell the truth" to the traveling public - despite many carriers commitments to inform passengers about the true causes for delay and to keep them informed in a timely manner, nothing has really changed.  On a number of flights, the pilot will announce a reason for delay, only to change the story 30 minutes later.  When waiting at the gate, the gate agents announce the outbound flight was delayed only to later announce there was a mechanical issue.  I think the public has a right to know what is causing delays (consistent mechanical issues, for example, would certainly allow me to  make an informed decision about who I choose to travel with).

Title: Dan Moore
Comment: These two airlines should NOT be allowed to engage in what would clearly be anti-competitive behavior.  BA should be forced to give up a signficant number of landing slots at Heathrow.  It is clear that even now, flying into LHR as compared to most other major European cities is significantly more expensive.  How is it that, from the US, one could fly to Paris and take the Eurostar train to London for LESS than flying direct to LHR?  Surely this is a clear sign of anti-competitive practice that will only get worse if BA and AA are allowed to work together more closely to harmonize fares (meaning, raise fares).

Title: Christopher A. Schutz
Comment:
I am concerned about the current state of our nation's transportation system. While cars and trucks provide important mobility, they also pollute the air and impair public health, the environment, and our communities. Efforts to build our way out of congestion by expanding highways only leaves more of us stuck in traffic without good alternatives. 

I urge you to support transportation reforms that protect the environment, enhance public health and safety, boost transportation choice, reduce sprawl and assure better public involvement and accountability for the effects of transportation decisions. As you consider reauthorization of the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21), please work to: 

- Expand Protection of Air and Water Quality The federal Congestion Mitigation Air Quality Program should be increased proportionate to the growing population in areas not meeting air quality standards. Boost funding and incentives for use of best storm-water management practices and environmental impact mitigation on roads. 
- Bolster Accountability for Public Health and the Environment Assure timely attainment of new air quality standards that protect public health. Strengthen oversight of transportation and air quality planning with better accounting for the indirect impacts of road expansion on traffic, land use, and pollution. Boost incentives and funds for state and local consideration of alternative strategies to reduce traffic and pollution. 
- Support Smart Incentives such expanding incentives for employers to pay for public transit benefits, 
- Level the Playing Field between Road Building and Transit Alternatives New road projects should meet the same criteria and funding requirements as new transit projects. 
- Oppose Environmental Streamlining.  Preserve the public's role in helping to plan highway projects. Oppose bills like "Expedite" that would weaken environmental laws to build roads faster. Instead support better integration of transportation, land use, and natural resource planning and environmental reviews so bad projects are screened out early and good alternatives advance faster. 
These policies ensure that transportation agencies will become better stewards of our environment and communities. Thank you for your support.

Title: Greg Zagaja
Comment:
As resident of NJ, I strongly believe that the government must get serious about building a strong, national intercity passenger rail network. We (Americans) are tired of being denied the transportation choices so readily available elsewhere in the world.  
 
I am writing to ask your support to keep Amtrak running. Amtrak needs $1.2 billion this year (should get 2.0B). And, most of all, it needs a long-term reauthorization so it can stop sliding from crisis to crisis. America deserves a first class rail passenger service. No passenger rail service in the world is profitable. It was wrong for Congress to demand that Amtrak become the only passenger railroad in the world to be self-sufficient. Amtrak already recovers more money from revenue than most other passenger railroads in the world. 
Living in an area that is serviced by the Acela Express, I can testify first hand of its benefits:  Convenient, no airport hassles, fast, provides an alternative (competition) to airlines and cars, and is environmentally efficient.  Therefore, positive externality to society greatly outweighs its cost.  However, due to the lack of funding, Amtrak has reduced the frequency of this great service to society and hasnt been able to upgrade the infrastructure in order to run this train at its maximum potential of 150 MPH; this speed was attained in Japan 35 years ago.    Ultimately, US rail travel is 30 to 40 years behind our European and Japanese economic rivals.
In addition, this kind of investment causes a unique phenomenon in the local economies it affects.  It promotes more clustered development, investment from the private sector around the high-speed infrastructure, migration and increased entrepreneurial spirit, and creates jobs for all levels of the social stratums.   In a time of economic and foreign crisis, what better way to provide redundancy to highways and airports and economic development to create jobs than to invest in rail.
Please increase your 2004 budget for Amtrak, and work with congress in a bi-partisan fashion in developing a national high-speed network of trains.  Highways and airports receive 33 billion and 17 billion respectively in subsidies {2002}, yet Amtrak is given a hard time receiving 2 billion.   Such an imbalance in subsidies provides an in-efficient market and a comparative advantage towards automobiles and airplanes.  I am a strong supporter of laissez faire economics, but I also believe in a fair and  efficient market place.  Therefore, funding for rail should be increased.  
I am very pleased with the job the US Congress has done, but leadership for an integrated multi-mode (Road, Rail, Air, & Sea) national infrastructure policy has been absent in this country for over 50 years.  The roads and airways have become increasingly congested, but our rails have been neglected.  They use a fraction of the land area roads use, pollute much less than other modes, and are much more energy efficient (Trains are energy-efficient -- Intercity (Amtrak) trains are far more efficient than airlines (2441 Btu's per passenger-mile vs. 3999 for airlines in 1998, according to the Oak Ridge National Laboratory). 
Ultimately, with so much talk about the environment, reducing our dependence on foreign oil, air quality, urban sprawl, airport and highway congestion, September 11th, sagging economy, and desperately needed redundancy in our transportation system, we cannot afford to continue neglecting such a valuable resource. The time to invest in High Speed passenger rail is now.
Thank you for all your hard work!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Greg Zagaja
Comment:
To whom it may concern.

The purpose of this message is to outline my concerns on the imbalanaced policy in transportation. (33B Highways, 18B Airports/airliners, 6.8B Transit, Rail..NONE?  1.2B?amtrak?) There is no formal agency to invest, plan and research for rail.  In addition With such a subsidy impbalance towards cars and airliners, there isn't fair competition among all three major transportation options (GROUND).  Funding for rail MUST be increased!  WE must plan, invest, and research to a national (TGV/ICE/Shinkasen)High Speed rail network for passengers and freight.  Rail uses a fraction of the land use, energy use, pollution output, and can handle far greater frieght and passenger capacity than roads.  Please increase amtrak funding, but most of all investment into high speed rail infrastructure!

Greg

Title: Donna Burck
Comment: I am a 44 year-old wheelchair user that lives in Anne Arundel County, Maryland.  There is no lift-equipped van service in Anne Arundel County, other than in the Annapolis area, which is limited in operation to only the Annapolis area.  I live in Glen Burnie, Maryland, and at the present time, I have to use the Mobility Van Service that is operated through the MTA in Baltimore.  Although it is affordable, it is not very reliable, as I am often late getting home, and sometimes I am too early to arrive at my destiantions! I have contacted the Anne Arundel County Director of Transportation in Anne Arundal County, Diane Matland, and while she sympathized, I was informed that there wasn't enough money in the County budget to accomodate the disabled people here in Anne Arundel County with a lift-equipped van service!  I feel that this is a great disservice to the disabled community here in A.A. County, (of which, there are thousands), but I am at a loss as to what I can do.  Disabled people are always encouraged to get off the SSI payroll, and be productive citizens, but that is extremely difficult if there is no adequate and reliable transportation to allow us to accomplish this simple goal.  Thank you.  Sincerely, dmburck1959@hotmail.com

Title: Criss N. Wilson
Organization Name: Kelley Drye & Warren LLP Michael J. Francesconi
Comment:
If you hold DHL to the rule that 75% of its shareholders must be US citizens, the the DOT must be prepared to hold UPS and FEDX to the same ruling.  If all three conditions must be present for a carrier to be considered a US citizen, the all three should be checked to insure their compliance to the stated 75% ownership rule.  How can a Mutli National Corporation like UPS or FEDX argue shareholder citizenship. Are they prepared to relinquish their priviledges as an airline should they fail the test of US citizenship?  I am a Transportation professional.  Believe me when I say that US companies pay to much for parcel services because of the lack of competition.  UPS and FEDX know their margins will shrink if competition is allowed to prevail, which is why they've pull out all the stops.  Pls be fair in the test of citizenship by applying it to DHL, UPS, and FEDX before you pass judgement on DHL  


For a carrier to qualify as a U.S. citizen, it must be incorporated in the United States, its president and two-thirds of its board of directors must be U.S. citizens, and at least 75 percent of its voting stock must be owned by U.S. citizens.  In addition, the department must find that the carrier is effectively controlled by U.S. citizens.

Title: Kimberly S. Goetz
Comment:
While I thank the Department for providing an opportunity for comment, I strongly disagree with the Departments proposal to adjust the current size standards for airport concessionaires due to the concession fees paid to airports.

Petitioners are correct in that the current size standards hamper the firms ability to retain DBE status.  However, Petitioners are incorrect that the current size standards hamper the firms ability to grow; to the contrary, that the firms gross receipts exceed the applicable size standards fully demonstrates the firms financial success.  Not only has the firm been able to grow and prosper, it has done so to an amazing extent.  A firms ability to retain DBE status despite its phenomenal success cannot, in and of itself, be justification for changing the rules to the firms further benefit.

Petitioners have argued that the imposition of uniform size standards creates a disparity between firms in different industries.  However, this argument ignores the actual financial situation of restaurants, retail outlets, and car rental agencies.  

Commissions paid to airports are simply a cost of doing business for all airport concessionaires.  Unlike food and beverage, retail, and car rental concessionaires, advertising agencies do not have other relatively high costs of doing business.  Advertising agencies have fewer employees than other concessionaires.  Advertising agencies do not need to purchase and maintain large numbers of automobiles.  Advertising agencies do not have to pay for and retain large inventories of books, sundries, foodstuffs, or related items.  The differences in commissions paid to airports actually level the playing field between different types of concessionaires by leveling their respective costs of doing business.

Petitioners argument also fails to consider the already increased size standards for airport concessionaires.  If Petitioners were applying for DBE certification as an FHWA contractor, their average annual gross receipts would be limited to just $5 million.  By establishing the $30/$40 million size standards, the Department has already recognized and accounted for the increased costs and higher revenues associated with airport operations.

While the Department (with its comprehensive view of airport concessionaires nationwide) may determine that $68.65 million in gross receipts per year reasonably constitutes a small business, the Department cannot expect either the general public nor members of Congress to understand or agree with that determination.  As the Department has not yet adopted a Personal Net Worth limitation for owners of airport concessionaires, there does not appear to be a way the Department can guarantee that DBE concessionaire owners are, in fact, socially and economically disadvantaged.  

The dramatically increase of (at least some) concessionaire size standards, combined with the lack of Personal Net Worth limitations, gives credence to DBE opponents and their arguments.  In the Departments final rule publication, the Department noted at 64 FR 5098:  The basic thrust of their argument was that if the program does not exclude wealthy members of the designated groups  meaning those who are not, in fact, disadvantaged  then it is overinclusive and therefore not narrowly tailored.  Whether or not this argument is correct is not relevant to the current NPRM.  However, it will be relevant to current and future challenges to the DBE program.

Petitioners may no longer be eligible for DBE certification, but this fact does not directly alter the establishment of participation goals.  For every firm which enjoys sufficient success to graduate from the DBE program, new participation opportunities for smaller firms are created.  While the Department should not discourage firms (such as Petitioners) from attempting to make the most of every potential business opportunity, it should likewise not discourage small firms from attempting to expand into the concessionaire market.

I encourage the Department to remember that graduated firms are still counted towards participation goals for the duration of their current contract (which could be up to ten years).  If a firm ceases to meet the DBE certification requirements, it will not be removed from any contracts and will not incur undue financial losses or penalties.

Finally, the proposed increase in size standards will further encourage large (sometimes multinational) corporations to own locations in multiple jurisdictions.  Instead of creating an environment dedicated to free and fair competition among many small firms, the increased size standard will promote the increasingly common practice of multiple DBE firms being owned by a single group of affiliates.  The Department should continue to promote competition, not monopoly-type behavior.

The Departments current size standards do not create a disparate system, but instead eliminate potential disparity in concessionaire contracting.  I strongly encourage the Department to reject the Petitioners request and to maintain its current size standard limitations for all concessionaires.

Title: Tokyo Electron Texas, LLC
Comment:
My comment is against IATA's Resolution 502 to change the volumetric rate. As far as I know, nothing has changed in the world of air freight that would be a driver for changing the relationship between volume versus actual weight charges. If this presumption is correct, then IATA's proposed change looks like little more than a somewhat surreptitious way to increase revenues for airlines and freight forwarders. I say that it is "surreptitious" because the increased changes do not have to be explictly shown in the tariffs (other than perhaps a footnote). Another potentially unfair consequence of the proposed rates increase is that the increase is unevenly distributed and instead penalizes shippers with low density cargoes. If the airlines and forwarders need to increase their rates, then they should do so in the clear light of day and not try to hide it behind some arbitrary change to their volumetric weight calculation.

Title: CSTA
Comment:
I find the key elements concerning IATA Res 502 are not being properly explained especially in relation to IATA's role in the rules and regulation process. 
 
I've attached a link to nmfta, an organization dealing with "National Motor Freight Classification" which is a US trucking rate classification standard.  
When you review just the linked page you can see that the type of classification adjustment for trucking is very similar to what IATA is trying to do with CR 502.  

http://www.nmfta.org/whatisclass2.htm
 
And as you read through this rate classification it is not considered an anti-trust issue for trucking. It's only fair that the same consideration is given to air carriers. When you combine the US trucking practice, with the way I outline air-cargo rating below, you'll see it's virtually the same thing.

Please see detail below





 

 

The Justice Department has offered an opinion that IATA's request for a change the volume conversion factor is construed as an anti-trust issue. The volume issue is an adjustment to a standard conversion factor that already exists, which is outside the rate a carrier charges for the transaction.

 

At the bottom of this e-mail is a sample of an air-waybill. The key air-waybill components in question are as follows:

 

actual weight -chargeable weight - rate/charge - total 

 

The conversion factor impacts the chargeable weight only.

 

Ex: A shipment of one thousand pillows weighs 500 lbs yet takes up the volume equivalent of 4000 lbs of space on an aircraft. The adjustment of the conversion factor proposed by IATA is actually saying that based on the volume of space, these pillows take up  4680 lbs of space on the aircraft.

 

Now this is how the air-waybill would be rated following the air-waybill example below.

 

                 pieces        actual weight    chargeable weight        rate/charge     total

Carrier A   1000            500 lbs            4680lbs                        .50/per lb       $2340

Carrier B   1000            500 lbs            4680lbs                        .40/per lb       $1872

Carrier C   1000            500 lbs            4680lbs                        .30/ per lb      $1404

 

In each of these examples the actual and chargeable weight remain the same yet the per lb rates are the rates the carrier provides the freight forwarder.

 

Things the DOJ must consider:

1) In 90% of the cases it's the freight forwarder that shops around for the rate from the carrier.   

2) More than 85% of all airfreight shipments in the non-integrated cargo environment is done through an industry practice called consolidation.  Basically the forwarder will consolidate a bunch of shipments to the same destination and in doing so will try and mix some volume freight with dense car

Title: Cargo Shipping Transporation Analysis
Comment:
The attached document will illustrate the change in packaging techniques by shippers that erode the carrier's ability to charge appropriate volume. 



Similar issues in the trucking industry also require the occasional adjustment of commodity classification based on density, packaging, and value.

See attached link http://www.nmfta.org/whatisclass2.htm



 Since deregulation airfreight net -rates are lower now than back in 1975. Between the carrier - forwarder there are "Net-Net¿,¿ Contract", "Density" and "Spot" rating schemes which vary from carrier to carrier. The proposed adjustment to the conversion factor is based on changes in packaging which when looking at the illustrations attached, is clearly taking up more space on the aircraft.  The pictures were taken from 4 different carriers and of 5 different shippers and commodities. If the volume calculation is not adjusted how does the carrier re-coop the lost revenue from these shipments? They can¿t.  



The competitiveness of air-transport rating is not going to change as a result of this rule. Carriers can select to apply volume or not apply it that will not change. 



I¿ve extracted an excerpt defining the basic premise of antitrust ¿The historic goal of the antitrust laws is to protect economic freedom and opportunity by promoting competition in the marketplace. Free competition benefits consumers through lower prices, better quality, and greater choice. Competition provides businesses the opportunity to compete on price and quality, in an open market and on a level playing field, unhampered by anticompetitive restraints.¿



The key is making the playing field level for all parties concerned and as a result, the integrity of antitrust remains 100% uncompromised with the adjustment to the volume standard.

Title: Kara L. Hope
Comment: As a Victoria air traveler-I would like to make my opinion known regarding the decision you will be making that affects all of us Victorians.I travel(fly) out of Victoria on average once a year on vacation.I already have tickets in fact for my vacation in June of this year.I was very disappointed to hear about Continental's decision to pull out.Right now I am hoping they will be still flying in June so I don't have to change any of my tickets or flight plans.I would consider it a major inconvenience to have to drive to Houston to fly out of a major airport for any air travel.I would not be interested in the Mesa proposal as it would fly to Dallas,which would make it harder(and more expensive) to make a connecting flight.Also it has the highest subsidy rate-which is crazy.The Skywest proposal sounds like it would make the most sense,as it would connect up with Continental flights(to make connections at a lower rate) in Houston. The fare is the lowest which would attract customers-but the subsidy rate is middle of the road.Continental only wants $400 K subsidy which is less than all the other proposals so far.The Great Lakes proposal's fare is the highest of all 3 which makes it the least attractive.I wish if Continental would continue to fly out of Victoria thru June(as planned) they would change the flight times on the last returning flight to the 9:30pm flight so you would have plenty of time to make all your travel connections and still get back to Victoria.As it stands,if Continental is flying with the times they have given I will have to redo tickets for my vacation June 16th.This has all been very stressful.As a regular person who works full time and plans all year for one 2 wk vacation,it is really hard to not know what you will be doing a month from now when you are leaving.We bought our tickets early thinking that would be a good thing to have confirmed tickets/plans but now it seems that we spent $1000 and don't even know anything with any degree of certainty.We have even thought several times about just canceling the tickets all together.I know this is a very long comment but I just wanted to let someone know what a average person is thinking who has been paying very close attention to all the FAA decisions(and how it affects me in the long and short term).Thanks for listening.

Title: Stephanie H. Dahl
Comment: I am a native Victorian whose Mother still lives there. I have been living in the New York area for over 30 years, and she and I have been making regular trips back and forth three or four times a year all that time. Air travel into Victoria, in terms of expense, scheduling and general uncertainty, has been a problem we have learned to live with, begrudgingly. Things were just starting to get a bit better recently, when Continental Express started using larger planes, and now here we are again... I am presently trying to make reservations for a mid-June flight from LGA to VCT and it seems impossible to plan. Guess I'll have to rent a car, again, from Houston, pay outrageous inter-city drop-off fees, and deal with whether or not the Victoria Airport is even open to return the vehicle! Since I've been through this so often, my vote for a new carrier would definitely be for one that services Houston, because at least those of us who end up having to drive to Victoria because of eratic air service can do so in three hours from IAH.

Title: John W. Griffin
Comment:
The selection of a carrier to serve the Victoria Regional Airport should take into account the likely success of the carrier.  Skywest clearly has the financial and marketing strength to eventually be profitable in this market.  Skywest will codeshare with Continental Airlines, and pending final approval, Delta Airlines and Continental will have a codeshare agreement.  

While the subsidy of Skywest is higher up front than one of the competing bids, that must be tempered by the likelihood of future profitability, and frequency of service using familiar EMB 120 aircraft may cost more up front, but that will ensure better traffic into our airport.

It is vital to the success of this airport that the selected carrier be able to feed into IAH, where Continental Airlines dominates, and Skywest wants to make good use of a seamless relationship with that carrier.  The other two proposals do not compare favorably at all with that of Skywest.

Finally, I serve as managing partner of our firm, and serve as past president of the community's annual Bach Festival.  I can assure the DOT that this community will make good use of the fine facility we have and will work to ensure profitability for Skywest, as we know subisidies are not designed for perpetuity.  We look forward to the selection of Skywest.  Thank you.

John Griffin, Jr.
Victoria TX
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: William J. Price
Comment:
The following comments are offered regarding Air carrier service to Victoria, Texas:

I have been flying in and out of Victoria, Texas for the past 28 years.  Many of my flights involved flying to the Eastern part of the US, and a good number of the flights also involved international travel (both business and pleasure trips).  I used to fly frequently on business, and found the EMB-120 type aircraft flying between Victoria and Houston to be reasonably fast and efficient.  The new jet service instated by Continental Express recently did not improve the flight time by a significant amount and the jet aircraft were more cramped in the seating arrangement.  I have been on many flights on the EMB-120 when only 4 or 5 seats were not filled so I believe that the smaller capacity Beech 1900 (proposed by Great Lakes) would not provide adequate service to the Victoria area.

In the last two to three years I have found that Continentals fare structure has made it significantly more expensive to fly out of Victoria.  This is significant enough that for pleasure trips (4 to 5 times a year), I have found that it is more cost effective to drive to San Antonio, pay a parking fee for a week or two and fly out of San Antonio (and usually end up going through Houston).  Since there are two people flying on these trips, Continental has lost out on 8 to 10 passenger round trips out of Victoria per year from my personal travel.

One of the benefits of having an airline connect in Houston, instead of Dallas is that when you have weather or maintenance related problems affecting the flight service between Victoria and Houston you still have the option to drive to Houston to catch a connecting flight. (Which I have done on several occasions in the past).

It was disappointing to learn that only one of the air carriers showed enough interest in providing service to Victoria to actually visit the airport here and talk with the personnel concerning providing service.  It would seem that only SkyWest is genuinely interested in doing business to service this market area.

I have reviewed the proposals listed on your web site for the three airlines that submitted proposals and also the local newspaper reports of the various meeting of the Victoria County Airport commission.  As a result of my review I support SkyWest as the carrier to provide best overall service and customer support to the Victoria area. 

Sincerely,

William J. Price
26May03

Title: Tanana Air Service
Comment:
BEFORE THE 
	DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
	OFFICE OF THE SECRETARY
	WASHINGTON, D. C.



____________________________________
				    ]
	INTRA-ALASKA BUSH AND 	    ]	Docket OST-2003-14694
     MAINLINE SERVICE MAIL RATES    ]	Docket OST-2003-14695
____________________________________]
						

	COMMENTS IN RESPONSE TO PRELIMINARY
	FINDINGS AND SHOW CAUSE ORDER











Tanana Air Service 
Response
October 21, 2003

Communications with respect to this 
document should be addressed to :		Fred H. Ciarlo
						Tanana Air Service
						P.O. Box 60713
						Fairbanks, AK 99706
						tanana@polarnet.com
						907-474-0301


After reviewing the Show Cause Order 2003-10-10, the following comments are submitted:

Issue 3:  Submission of data as required on Appendix A is going to be a very difficult process. The data required are not clear, i.e., Non-Scheduled passenger and freight data Inbound. BTS has not had their system on the Internet since before this order was published and there is no guidance for the completion of this appendix. Also, the exclusion of carriers that do not expect to qualify for bypass mail will skew the data as incomplete for a given market.

Issue 5:   All other qualifications for a carrier to receive bypass mail has been and is still three flights a week. For the Department to arbitrarily reduce the requirement for a 19-seat passenger Part 121 aircraft to be flown into a market once a week to qualify as a Part 121 Bush rate is unreasonable and establishes a precedence that is unwarranted.

As stated in Issue 3, the completion of Appendix A in any meaningful manner, with the instructions provided, is impossible at this time to complete by November 1, 2003. BTS does not have their website on-line concerning Alaska Data, the requirement for inbound N-Skd Pass and Freight is unclear, and the communities are assumed to be only the hubs. 

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on these issues.
