Title: Roxanne Wyant
Comment:
FMCSA - 49 CFR Part 40 and Chapter 382 Controlled Substances and Alcohol Use and Testing

382.107 Defines Actual knowledge, to include ... a traffic citation for driving a CMV while under the influence of alcohol   According to the DOT trial attorney, this is because citation has credible evidence based on its presumed validity.

On that consensus, the DOT Enforcement and Compliance Officer and the DOT Trial Attorney, have determined that the company is regulated to suspend the CDL driver from safety sensitive duty and refer them for SAP evaluation and treatment, as per 40.285. 

However, the rule-maker for the DOT states The Company has no authority to act on the citation. Even if it were a DUI, the Company has no authority to suspend the driver. 

Q:What chance does the CDL driver have if the judicial system, legal pools and companies arent any more knowledgeable of CFR law than the DOTs own Compliance Officer and Trial Attorney?

According to FMCSA Regulation 382.109 is explained as Preemption of State and local laws.

Q: How does this work, when there is no judicial/hearing process on the Federal level for the State issued citation or the Company issued violation?
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: Center for Aerospace & Occupational Medicine
Comment:
There is a wide range of human physiology possible.  Just as it is possible to have a positive marijuana urine drug test from passive inhalation in extreme cases, so it is possible to reach such a dilution of urine as to meet the substituted criteria.  But in neither situation is it likely or even probable.  Just as passive inhalation is not a valid explanation for a positive marijuana, so should the extreme situation required to reach the substituted criteria for urine concentration not be used to explain the substituted urine specimen.



The DOT makes accommodation for the rare individual who might unwittingly produce a urine specimen meeting the substituted criteria by allowing such an individual to demonstrate, under the supervision of a physician, that they can physiologically produce a ¿substituted¿ urine specimen.  This seems an adequate safeguard for the very rare individual who might inadvertently provide an extremely dilute urine specimen meeting the substituted criteria while preserving the standard for the multitude of drug users who are trying to beat a positive drug test by purposefully creating a highly diluted urine specimen.

Title: Drug and Alcohol Testing Industry Association

Comment: Comments of the Drug and Alcohol Testing Industry Association regarding the Department of Transportation's interim final rule concerning reporting specimens as dilute or substituted.

Title: N.B. Varlotta
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: National Toxicology Specialists
Comment:
This latest development in the dilute urine issue is a tribute to the democratic process. I applaude the DOT in their diligence. 
I have long thought the solution to the whole dilution issue is to make the category all the same whether the creatinine is 19 or 1. Since the test is colorimetric and even mountain dew will show up with creatinine readings, it really is a poor test for validity. 
The problem is there have been very few prospective studies looking at the relationship of creatinine and specific gravity to make any kind of reasonable assertions. Until the DOT is willing to fund such a study with thousands of samples, any assertions are going to be fraught with inaccuracies and therefore open to challenge. 
Until that day, I recommend that all samples with any creatinine less than 20 but greater than 0 be treated as dilute and require that a direct observation sample must be collected immediately. Frankly, most if not all the employers I deal with re-collect all the dilute samples anyway, so this would not be any more of a financial burden as a practical matter.    
Any sample with no creatinine would still be reported as substituted. 
Again, I applaude the DOT for continuing to open this matter to discussion.
Sincerely, 
Greg Elam, M.D.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: postmarkDate, Answer Date, Date the document was postmarked

Title: WPCIDrugFree
Comment:
We have had 2 specimens in the last couple of weeks that were reported from the laboratory as " Invalid, no creatinine detected, specific gravity with range."  The laboratory rejected the specimen for testing.  The MRO called the certifying scientist and discovered that the specimen had the color and consistency of urine but had no detectable creatinine.  The MRO discussed this with the donor and the donor had no legitimate medical explanation for no creatinine in the specimen.  My understanding is the way the reg's are written now the MRO would "Cancel"  the test and  notify the DER that an immediate observed collection be done.  

 

I do not believe and neither do our Medical Review Officers that a person with no know medical condition that is walking around can produce a specimen with no creatinine.  This type of specimen appears to be a substituted specimen with the correct color and consistency but it is not a human urine.  Shouldn't this be as substituted.  This is our comment for the interim final rule on substitution and adulteration.

 

Dennis L. Kerns, V. P. Business Development

dkerns@wpcidrugfree.com

Phone:  800-682-5176

Fax:  308-632-7423

Title: Ronald Greene
Comment:
July 9, 2003


To all parties concerned,
As a previous employee (767 Captain) of (AAI) Air Atlanta Icelandic, I am aware of their intentions with their newly formed company (AAE) Air Atlanta Europe to conduct flights into the United States.

I have 3 main points of objection for granting any exemptions to Section 40109(c) of Title 49 of the United States Code and Part 302, Subpart C of the Deparatments Economic Regulations, requesting an exemption from 49 U.S.C. Section 41301.

1. Air Atlanta Icelandic's refusal to maintain a current database in their Boeing 767 aircraft's Flight Management Computers, or FMC. On numerous occasions I brought this to the attention of their aircraft maintenance technicians and yet they continued to operate the aircraft into major European destinations such as London Heathrow, and Paris Charles de Gaulle, France, as well as occasional flights into the United States, New York JFK's Int'l airport in particular.

2. Pilot Training, Air Atlanta Icelandic contracted with numerous vendors to conduct their training. This led to a lack of continuity in their operating procedures. AAI used companies as Britannia, British Airways, JMC, and others. 

3. Allowing Air Atlanta's new creation (AAE) to operate into the United States would add a new competitor to the already troubled airline industry here in the United States.

As a Captain with first hand knowledge of Air Atlanta's way of conducting their operations. I would be apprehensive of their new entrant to the industry to be operated in the same fashion as they operate AAI at the present time.

Thank you for allowing me to comment.

Ronald Greene
Former B767 Captain for AAI, Air Atlanta Icelandic.

Title: Chubb Group
Comment:
The Truckload Carriers Assocation's petition requesting an exemption on financial reporting would greatly affect Marine Underwriters' ability to properly assess a carrier.  The financial status of a motor carrier is an important measure of the potential for bankruptcy and/or fraudulent loss exposure.  If this exemption is granted, we underwriters would lose the most fundamental piece of information essential to our analysis.  
With respect to preserving confidential business information, I don't see how facilitating insurers' awareness on a motor carrier's financial standing would contribute to "competitive harm".  On the contrary, the periodic reporting of the carrier's status is a great way to evaluate and prevent financial problems, therefore mitigating losses to the carrier himself as well as his insurer. Overall, if carriers no longer report their financial, insurers will be greatly hindered in their ability to write Motor Truck Cargo business.

I believe DOT is looking for public comments about the new petition as

After reading the latest article about the petition filed by the Truckload

reports with DOT's Bureau of Transportation Statistics, I feel the need to

Title: Stephen V. Burks
Comment:
Comments for Office of the Secretary, USDOT, Docket No. OST-2003-15794
Motor Carrier Financial Information Reporting RequirementsRequest for Public Comments

Comments by Stephen V. Burks, Ph.D. 
Assistant Professor of Economics and Management, 
University of Minnesota, Morris.

These comments are on my own behalf.

1.  	I currently make significant use of the data submitted by trucking firms on the Form M, and have done so also with its predecessors.  For example, my doctoral dissertation in economics used Form M data, and I am currently working on an academic paper using Form M data with a colleague and a student.  I anticipate continuing to do use these data as part of my professional academic duties in the future.  
	I have also been involved in the independent collection of new industry data by academic researchers, some of which is proprietary and held confidential, and some of which is able to be made publicly available, and I am of the strong opinion that the value of what is thus collected is leveraged and enhanced for many purposes by the existence and quality of the Form M data set.  
	The Form M data provide critical resources to researchers, including myself, who are evaluating public policy questions of vital concern to the government, the industry, and the general public.  Such studies include an analysis of the impact of the recent changes in the hours of service regulations imposed on commercial vehicle operators employed by the industry, and an analysis of the effect of method of pay and level of pay on driver safety performance.  Scholars also use these data to examine the annual earnings trends in the industry, in comparison with those in the economy as a whole, in studies of wage inequality in competitive economies; the data on work time and earnings provide critical variables for analysis.  Additionally, scholars use these data to look at features of the industry that assist in the development of theoretical work within their particular disciplines (e.g. the field of industrial organization within economics), and to advance scholarly understanding of the industry, and its contribution to and role in the larger U.S economy.  

2.	I do not believe that the criteria used to evaluate whether a carrier has demonstrated whether it will suffer competitive harm by release of its financial information should be changed.  
	Trucking is a very competitive industry with relatively easy entry requirements (especially in the truckload segment of the petitioners), and modest amounts of fixed capital investment compared to truly capital-intensive industries.  Competitive advantage is necessarily transitory in such an industry, and this is exactly the desired public policy result of the industry deregulation of 1980, because it ensures that each firm is always forced to meet the competition in terms of significant innovations.  The annual reports at the level of relatively coarse financial detail required by the Form M are good, albeit lagging, indicators of overall competitive success, but they do not generally give competitors access to useful strategic information, and certainly do not generally do so in a shorter time than the normal routes of diffusion of knowledge within the industry (such as turnover of managers, sales efforts by vendors, etc.) provide.  Therefore, the petitioners argument that the BTS is failing to exercise its delegated authority to grant reporting relief is likely accurate, but incomplete, because it leaves out the fact that the BTS decisions have been appropriate and proper, given the inability of petitioners for relief to show credible evidence of harm.  
	Few privately held firms like to have their financial information in the public domain, but establishing dislike is not the same as showing that their financial growth or operational success is measurably inhibited thereby.  It is worth remembering that corporations are chartered by states in the first place because doing so serves public purposes such as economic growth and job creation.  A corporate charter imposes a burdento meet the lawful requirements of the public, such as the historically and currently important Form M reporting requirementsand being privately held does not remove this legal and moral burden.  

3.	I believe that the current reporting thresholds should be retained, with two qualifications, one major, and one minor.  
	The major point: there should be an immediate lowering of the Class III threshold, in order to require limited basic information from all firms that operate with a separate carrier identification.  This information should include the (1) name of the firm, (2) its primary business location, (3) some measure of its size, such as the average number of drivers and/or independent contractor drivers employed, or the total annual revenue, (4) a categorization of the type of freight that generates the majority of the firms revenue, and (5) an estimate of the proportion of that revenue generated under the firms own carrier identification, as opposed to revenue generated while providing purchased transportation services to another carrier.  It would greatly enhance the ability of economists to analyze the structure of the motor carrier industry to have a current basic census of all the firms that are competing.  
	The minor point: if some basic reporting is required of small carriers, then since inflation slowly changes the value of the dollar thresholds, I would regard it as reasonable to adjust what are currently defined as the Class I and Class II thresholds upward (or downward, if required by deflation) once every three or every five years, using the Producer Price Index or a more targeted variant, and making the adjustments in increments of $500,000.  If some basic reporting is not required of small carriers, then I believe the thresholds should be left where they are currently.  

4. I do not currently make use of the QFR, but I believe that its continued collection is helpful for the laudable BTS aim to make more transportation data available on a more timely basis.  

5. The DOT should not, in my opinion, eliminate any current lines items in the Form M. The current version strikes a reasonable balance between a lowered reporting burden, current usability, and the very critical factor, for assessing long term trends, of historical comparability with older versions that had more detailed reporting requirements.  

6. Not Applicable. 


As a professional academic analyst of the trucking industry (who is employed at a major public university, and who is commenting on his own behalf) I believe it would be inappropriate to grant the petitioners' request, and I state my grounds for this professinal opinion in detail.

Title: Penn State University, Smeal College of Business
Organization Name: Penn State University Smeal College of Business
Comment:
I ask the DOT not to discontinue this reporting.  This data is the only useful data on motor carriers that is available.  I and others use it for research in areas of safety, productivity, model efficiency, and other areas.  It is critically important that this information stream continue, especially now that there is little oversight of our most important industry.  It is important to understand that this data is used for many purposes that do not involve motor carriers directly.  Projects for capacity improvements in truck, rail, and other modes depend on accurate cost information that this data stream provides.

Additionally, since the report was streamlined, the report is significantly less onerous than it used to be.  What is it that some carriers want to hide?  Without this data we wouldn't have a clue.

Title: Michael H. Belzer
Comment:
Comments for Office of the Secretary, USDOT, Docket No. OST-2003-15794

Motor Carrier Financial Information Reporting RequirementsRequest for Public Comments

Comments by Michael H. Belzer, Ph.D. Associate Professor of Industrial Relations
Wayne State University

These comments are on my own behalf.


Over the years I have used Financial and Operating Statistics ("Form M") in my research many times.  I used Form M data in my doctoral dissertation on wage determination in the trucking industry after deregulation.  I used these data from the regulated period and from subsequent periods.  More recently, I led teams of researchers studying both truck driver hours of service and the relationship between truck driver pay and safety for the FMCSA.  We used these data at various during this research for both primary and secondary purposes.  That is, we used them both to test hypotheses and to verify other data sets we were using.  Most recently, I have been working with colleagues at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on truck safety research which, in part, uses these data.

These data are unusual insofar as they provide detailed insight into firms using public highways.  Just as driving is a privilege and not a right, we confer this privilege to motor carriers to use our highways as their business location.  They must in turn disclose more information on many aspects of their business operations in return for using these highways, and the data provided in Form M is part of that exchange.

I retain the only existing set of paper Form M dating from the end of the Interstate Commerce Commission back to approximately 1970, which is the entire history of the modern trucking industry in data form.  The BTS should be encouraged and funded to make these data also available to other researchers, as I have had to bear the cost of maintaining these files privately for many years.  If they were available, researchers could expand the state of knowledge of historical trends in this industry and resolve many other questions of historical interest that require financial and operating data.

Frankly, I would argue that the current F & OS data should include a number of additional items that could help researchers better understand the connections between trucking company finances and operations and truck safety.  This is a growing area of interest as scholars and others search for alternative means of benchmarking motor carrier safety.

I do not believe that the criteria used to evaluate whether a carrier has demonstrated whether it will suffer competitive harm by 
release of its financial information should be changed.  We have debaded this issue repeatedly and at great length and no showing of competive harm has been demonstrated.

I believe that the current reporting thresholds should be extended, as data on Class III carrires should be required to a much lower threshold.  These data can be linked to MCMIS data and others, allowing a more robust analysis of the relationship between financial and operating characteristics and motor carrier safety.

Indeed, I served on the National Research Council/Transportation Research Board panel providing oversight to FMCSA's Large Truck Crash Causation Study.  I recommended that the FMCSA and its contractors make a stronger effort to capture F&OS type data in that study and surveyors found it very difficult or impossible to collect it on carriers that had suffered crashes.  If these data were available on a larger number of firms, this research might have been more feasible.

I do not currently make use of the QFR.  

The DOT should not eliminate any current lines items in Form M. Indeed, the public would be well served by more data reporting, not less.
